Then let him boast. Who might offend, and has not offended? Or may do evil, and has not done it? His goods shall be established,
And the assembly shall declare his kind deeds. If you sit at a plentiful table, do not be greedy on it,
And do not say, “There is much food on it.” Remember that an evil eye is wickedness;
And what is created more evil than an eye? Therefore it weeps at every occasion. Do not stretch your hand wherever you look,
And do not thrust with it into the dish. Do not judge your neighbour by yourself;
But be discerning in every matter. Eat as is allowed, that which is put before you;
But do not devour, lest you be hated. For the sake of manners, be first to cease;
And do not be gluttonous, lest you cause stumbling. When you sit among many,
Do not be the first to reach out your hand. A very little is sufficient for a man of discipline,
And he is not short of breath on his bed. Sound sleep comes from moderate eating;
He rises early, and is attentive; But the pain of worry, and bitterness, and stomach pangs, Are with a gluttonous man. 1173
Rise up, go vomit, and you shall have rest. My son, listen to me, and do not despise me,
And in the end you shall find as I told you. In all your work be efficient, so that no sickness comes to you. Whoever is generous with his food, men shall
speak well of him; And the report of his good hospitality shall be believed. But against he who is greedy with his food, the
whole city shall murmur; And the report of his selfishness shall not be doubted. Do not show your boldness with wine;
For wine has destroyed many. The furnace proves the sword edge by dipping;
So wine tries the hearts of the proud in drunkenness. Wine is as good as life to a man, if it is drunk
moderately. What then is life to a man that is without wine? For it was made to make men glad. Wine drunk moderately and in season brings
gladness of the heart, And cheerfulness of the mind; But wine drunken in excess makes bitterness of
the mind, With brawling and quarreling. Drunkenness increases the rage of a fool till he
stumbles: It diminishes strength, and causes wounds. Do not rebuke your neighbour while at wine,
And do not despise him in his rejoicing; Give him no words of grief, and do not urge him on.
If you are appointed master do not lift yourself up, 1174
place, That you may rejoice with them, And receive a crown for your well ordering of the feast. Speak, you who are the elder, for it is fitting for
you, But with right-ruling; and do not withhold music. Do not pour out words when there is a musician,
And do not put forth wisdom out of time. A concert of music at a banquet of wine is as a
signet of ruby mounted in gold. As a signet of an emerald mounted in a work of
gold, So is the melody of music with pleasant wine. Speak, young man, if there is need of you;
And yet only twice when you are asked. Let your words be few, saying much with few
words; Be as one who knows and yet holds his tongue. If you are among great men, do not make yourself
equal with them; And when aged men are in place, do not use many words. Before the thunder goes lightning;
And before a humble man goes favour. Rise up early, and do not be the last;
And get home without delay. There fulfill your office, and do what you shall:
But do not sin with proud speech. And for these baraḵ He who made you,
And has filled you with His goodness. Whoever reveres HWHY shall receive His
discipline; And those who seek Him early shall find favour. 1175
But the hypocrite shall stumble over it. Those who revere HWHY shall find Right-Ruling,
And shall kindle righteousness as a light. A sinful man shall not be reproved,
But finds an excuse according to his liking. A man of counsel is considerate;
But a strange and proud man is not troubled by fear, Even when he himself has done without counsel. Do no deed without advice;
And when you are done, do not regret it. Do not go in a way in which you may fall,
And do not stumble among the stones. Do not be reckless on an easy road.
And beware of your own children.
In every good work guard your own being;
For this is the keeping of the Commands. He who believes in HWHY guards the Commands;
And he who trusts in Him does not come to harm.
No evil shall come upon he who reveres HWHY; And in trials He also shall deliver him. A wise man does not hate the Law;
But he who is a hypocrite in it, is like a ship in a storm. A man of understanding trusts in the Law;
And the Law is trustworthy to him, as a Word. Prepare what to say, and so you shall be heard;
And draw upon instruction, and then give answer. The heart of the foolish is like a cartwheel;
And his thoughts are like a rolling axle. A mocking friend is like a stallion,
He neighs under everyone that rides him. Why is one day better than another,
When all the light of every day of the year is from the sun? 1176
And He turns seasons and Feasts. Some of them He has made High Days, and
qadosh them, And some of them He has made regular days. And all men are from the ground,
And Aḏam was created from the earth. In much knowledge HWHY has spread them,
And made their ways different. Some of them He has baraḵ and exalted,
And some of them He qadosh, and placed near Himself; But some of them He has cursed and brought low, And removed from their places. As the clay is in the potter’s hand, to fashion it at
his desire; So is man in the hand of He who made him, To give unto them as He thinks best. Good opposes evil, and life against death;
So is the righteous against the sinner, and the wicked against the reverent. So look upon all the works of the Most High;
And there are pairs of two, one against another. I woke up last of all, as one that gathers after the
grape gatherers; By the beraḵah of HWHY I profited, and trod my winepress like a gatherer of grapes. Consider that I did not labour for myself only,
But for all those who seek learning. Hear me, O you great men of the people,
And listen with your ears, you rulers of the assembly. Do not give your son and wife, your brother and
friend, power over you while you live, And do not give your goods to another; Lest you reconsider, and you ask for its return. As long as you live and have breath in you,
Do not give yourself over to any. 1177
you, Than that you should stand to their sympathy. Be the best in all your works;
Do not leave a blot on your esteem. At the time when you shall end your days, and
finish your life, Distribute your inheritance. Fodder, a rod, and burdens, are for the donkey;
And bread, discipline, and work, for a servant. If you put your servant to labour, you shall find
rest: But if you let him go idle, he shall seek freedom. A yoke and a collar bow the neck;
So are tortures and punishment for an evil servant. Send him to work, so he is not idle;
For idleness teaches much evil. Put him to work, as is fit for him;
If he is not obedient, put on heavier shackles. But do not be excessive toward any;
And do naught without discretion. If you have a servant, let him be to you as
yourself, Because you have bought him for a price. If you have a servant, treat him as a brother;
For you have need of him, as of your own being. If you treat him evilly, and he runs from you, Which way shall you go to seek him?
The expectancies of a man of no understanding are empty and false; And dreams raise up fools. Whoever regards dreams is like he who catches
at a shadow, And follows after the wind. 1178
another, Even as the likeness of a face to a face. From an unclean matter, what may be cleansed?
empty; And imaginations of the heart, As the heart of a woman in childbirth. If they are not sent from the Most High in your
visitation, Do not lay your heart upon them. For dreams have deceived many,
And they have failed those who put their trust in them. The Law shall be found perfect without falsehood;
And wisdom is perfection to a trustworthy mouth. A man that has travelled knows much;
And he who has much experience shall declare wisdom. He who has no experience knows little;
But he who has travelled is full of insight. When I travelled, I saw much;
And I understand more than I could express. I was often in danger of death;
Yet I was delivered because of these: The spirit of those who revere HWHY shall live;
For their expectancy is in He who saves them. Whoever reveres HWHY shall not fear nor be
afraid; For He is his expectancy. Baruḵ is the being of he who reveres HWHY:
To whom does he look, and who is his strength? For the eyes of HWHY are upon those who love
Him, He is their mighty shield and strong support, A protection from heat, and a cover from the sun at 1179
He gives health, ḥai, and beraḵah. He who offers of what is wrongfully gotten, his
offering is a mockery; And the gifts of unrighteous men are not accepted. The Most High is not pleased with the offerings of
the wicked; Nor is He appeased by the multitude of offerings for sin. Whoever brings an offering from the goods of the
poor, Does as one that kills the son before his father’s eyes. The bread of the needy is their life;
He who deprives him of it is a man of blood. He who takes away the livelihood of his neighbour
slays him; And he who deprives the labourer of his wage is a shedder of blood. When one builds, and another pulls down,
What profit do they have but labour? When one prays, and another curses,
Whose voice shall HWHY hear? He who washes himself after touching a dead
body, If he touches it again, what use is his washing? So it is with a man that fasts for his sins, and goes
again, and does the same; Who shall hear his prayer, or what does his humbling profit him?
He who guards the Law brings offerings enough; He who guards the Command offers a peace offering. 1180
And he who gives in kindness offers praise. To depart from wickedness is pleasing to HWHY;
And to forsake unrighteousness is an atonement. You shall not appear empty-handed before HWHY.
For all these are because of the Command.
The offering of the righteous makes the altar fat,
And its sweet savour is before the Most High. The offering of a righteous man is acceptable.
And the remembrance of it shall never be forgotten. Give HWHY His esteem with a good eye,
And do not diminish the first-fruits of your hands. In all your gifts show a cheerful face,
And dedicate your tithes with gladness. Give to the Most High according to His enrichment
unto you; And as you have received, give with a cheerful eye. For HWHY repays,
And shall give you seven times as much. Do not think to corrupt with gifts; for He does not
accept these: And do not trust in unrighteous offerings; For HWHY is Judge, and with Him is no partiality. He shows no partiality against the poor,
But shall hear the prayer of the oppressed. He shall not despise the prayer of the fatherless;
Nor the widow, when she pours out her complaint. Do not the tears run down the widow’s cheeks?
And is not her cry against he who causes them to fall? He who HWHY serves shall be accepted with
favour, And his prayer reaches to the clouds. The prayer of the humble pierces the clouds;
And he shall not be comforted till it comes near; And shall not depart, till the Most High executes right- ruling and judgment. 1181
patient toward them,
deeds, And to the works of men according to their schemes; Till He has judged the cause of His people, And caused them to rejoice in His kindness. Favour is welcomed in the time of affliction,
As clouds of rain in the time of drought.
Show favour upon us, O HWHY Elohim of all, and look on us; And send Your fear upon all the nations that do
not seek You. Lift up Your hand against the foreign nations,
And let them see Your strength. As You were qadosh in us before them:
So You be exalted among them before us. And let them know You, as we have known You,
That there is no Elohim but You alone, O Elohim. Show new signs, and make other awesome
wonders; Esteem Your hand and Your right arm, That they may put forth Your wondrous works. Raise up displeasure, and pour out wrath;
Remove the adversary, and destroy the enemy. Shorten the time, remember the Covenant,
And let them declare Your wonders. Let he who escapes be consumed by the rage of
the fire; And let those who oppress the people perish. 1182
say, “There is no one else but us!” Gather all the tribes of Ya’aqoḇ together;
Your inheritance, as from the beginning. O HWHY, show favour upon the people that are
called by Your Name, And upon Yisra’ĕl, whom You have named Your first- born.
The place of Your rest. Fill Tsiyon with Your unspeakable words,
And Your people with Your esteem. Give witness to those who You have possessed
from the beginning, And raise up neḇi’im that are for Your Name. Reward those who wait for You,
And let Your neḇi’im be found trustworthy. O HWHY, hear the prayer of Your servants,
According to the beraḵah of Aharon over Your people, That all those who dwell on the earth may know that You are HWHY, The Elohim of old. The stomach consumes all foods,
Yet one meat is better than another. As the mouth tastes different kinds of game;
So does a heart of understanding false speeches. A crooked heart causes grief;
But a man of experience shall repay him. A woman shall accept any man,
Yet one daughter is better than another. The loveliness of a woman cheers the face,
And there is naught a man loves better. If there is kindness, meekness, and comfort, in her
tongue, Then her husband is not like other men. 1183
A help like himself, and a pillar of rest. Where no wall is, there possessions are
plundered; And he who has no wife shall wander about sighing. Who shall trust a crafty thief that skips from city to
city? Even so a man that has no house, and lodges wherever the night takes him?
Every friend says, “I am his friend also.” But there is a friend, which is only a friend in name. Is it not a grief unto death,
When a companion and friend is turned to an enemy? O wicked thoughts, where have you come from,
To cover the earth with deceit? There is a companion, who rejoices in the
prosperity of a friend, But in the time of trouble shall be against him. There is a companion, who helps his friend for his
stomach, And takes up a shield against the enemy. Do not forget your friend in your heart,
And do not forget him in your wealth. Every counsellor extolls counsel;
But some who counsel for themselves. Beware of a counsellor, and know before what
need he has; For he shall counsel for himself; And cast the lot against you, And say to you, “Your way is good.”
And afterward stand on the other side, to see what shall befall you. Do not consult with one that suspects you;
And hide your counsel from those who envy you. Nor consult with a woman regarding she of whom
she is jealous; 1184
Whom you know to guard the Commands of HWHY, Whose, mind is according to your mind, And shall grieve with you, if you fail. And let the counsel of your own heart stand;
For there is no man more trustworthy to you than it. For the mind of a man sometimes tells him more
than seven watchmen, That sit above in a high tower. And above all this, pray to the Most High,
And counsel before every action. The face is a sign of changing of the heart.
Four ways of all are apparent:
Good and evil, life and death; But the tongue rules over them continually. There is one who is wise and teaches many,
And yet does not profit himself. There is one who shows wisdom in words, and is
hated; He shall be destitute of all food. For favour is not given to him from HWHY,
Because he has neglected all wisdom. Another is wise to himself;
And the fruits of understanding are as praise in his mouth. 1185
And the fruits of his understanding do not fail. A wise man shall be filled with bireḵoth;
And all those who see him shall regard him as baruḵ. The days of the life of man may be numbered;
But the days of Yisra’ĕl are without number. A wise man shall inherit esteem among his
people, And his name shall be forever. My son, prove your being in your life,
And see what is evil for it, and do not give in to it. For not all is profitable for all men,
Nor has every being pleasure in every matter. Do not be gluttonous in any delicacy,
Nor too greedy with food; For excess of food brings sickness,
And gluttony shall turn to disgust. Many have perished by gluttony;
But he who guards himself prolongs his life.
Esteem a physician with the esteem due to him for the uses which you may have for him: For HWHY has created him. For healing comes from the Most High,
And He shall receive esteem from the sovereign. The skill of the physician shall raise his head;
And in the sight of great men he shall be admired. HWHY has created medicines out of the earth;
And he who is wise does not reject them. Was not the water made sweet with wood,
That its power might be known? And He has given men skill,
That He might be esteemed by His marvellous works. With such He heals and takes away their pains.
Of such the perfumer makes a perfume;
And of His works there is no end; And from Him there is peace over all the earth. 1186
But pray to HWHY, and He shall heal you. Cease from sin, and order your hands well,
And cleanse your heart from all wickedness. Offer a sweet fragrance, and a remembrance of
fine flour; And make an offering of fat of your being. So give place to the physician, for HWHY has
created him; Do not let him leave you, for you have need of him. There is a time when there is good success in
their hands. For they shall also pray to HWHY,
That He would prosper that which they give, For ease and health to prolong life. He who sins before his Maker,
Let him fall in the hand of the physician. My son, let tears fall down over the dead,
And begin to lament, as if you had suffered great harm yourself; And then cover his body according to the custom, And do not neglect his burial. Weep bitterly, and make a great mourning with
lamentation, as he is worthy, And that a day or two, lest you are spoken evil of; And then comfort yourself for your grief. For from grief comes death, and heaviness of the
heart destroys strength. In affliction sorrow also remains;
And the life of the poor is the curse of the heart. Take no grief to heart;
Drive it away, and remember the latter end. Do not forget it, for there is no returning again;
You shall do him no good, but harm yourself. “Remember my judgment; for so shall yours
be also... Yesterday for me, and today for you.” 1187
rest; And be comforted for him, when his spirit has departed from him. The wisdom of a learned man comes by
opportunity of leisure; And he who has little business may become wise. How shall he who holds the plough attain wisdom,
And who sharpens the goad, who drives oxen, and is occupied in their labour, and whose talk is of bulls? He gives his mind to making furrows;
And is diligent to give the cattle fodder. So every carpenter and worker, that labours night

and day; And those who cut and engrave seals, And are diligent to make great variety, and give themselves to copy imagery, and watch to finish a work; Also the smith sitting by the anvil, and considering

the iron work, The smoke of the fire weakens his flesh, and he fights the heat of the furnace; The noise of the hammer and the anvil is constantly in his ears, and his eyes are fixed on the pattern of that which he makes; He applies his mind to finish his work, And watches to polish it perfectly. So the potter sits at his work,
And turns the wheel around with his feet, Who is always focused at his work, and makes all his work by number; He moulds the clay with his arm, and bows down
his strength before his feet; He applies himself to the glazing; And he is diligent to clean the furnace. 1188
And everyone is skilled in his work. Without these a city cannot be inhabited;
And they could not dwell where they do, nor go up and down. They shall not be sought in public counsel, nor sit
high in the assembly;
And their desire is in the work of their craft.
But he who gives his mind to the Law of the Most High, And is occupied in the study of it, Seeks out of all the ancient wisdom, and is occupied in neḇuoth. He guards the sayings of the men of name;
And where wise parables are, he shall be there also.
And speak of hidden parables. He shall serve among great men, and appear
before princes; He shall travel through foreign countries; For he has examined the good and the evil among men. He applies his heart early to look to HWHY who
made him, And shall pray before the Most High, And opens his mouth in prayer, And makes supplication for his sins.
with the spirit of understanding; 1189
And on His secrets he meditates. He reveals that which he has learned,
And shall boast in the Law of the Covenant of HWHY. Many shall commend his understanding;
And as long as the world endures, it shall not be blotted out; His remembrance shall not depart, and his name shall live from generation to generation. Nations shall speak of his wisdom,
And the assembly shall declare him baruḵ. If he dies, he shall leave a greater name than a
thousand: And if he lives, he shall increase it. Yet I have more to say, which I have thought
upon; For I am filled as at the full moon.
And bud as a rose of the field growing by the wadi; And give a sweet fragrance as frankincense, and
flourish as a lily. Send out a fragrance, and sing a song of praise, Baraḵ HWHY in all His works. Exalt His Name, and extol His praise with the
songs of your lips, and with harps, And in praising Him you shall say after this manner: All the works of HWHY are exceedingly good,
And whatever He commands shall be accomplished in due season. And none shall say, “What is this?
Why is that?” For at an appropriate time they shall all be sought out: At His command the waters stood as a heap, 1190
And none reverses His deliverance. The works of all flesh are before Him,
And there is none hidden from His eyes. He sees from everlasting to everlasting;
And there is no matter too marvellous for Him. A man need not say, “What is this? Why is that?”
For He has made all for their uses. His beraḵah covered the dry land as a river,
And watered it as a flood. As He has turned the waters salty;
So shall the gentiles inherit His wrath.
So they are stumbling blocks to the wicked. The good matters are created for the good from
the beginning; So evil matters for sinners. The basic necessities for the whole use of man’s
life are: Water, fire, iron, and salt, flour of wheat, honey, milk, and the juice of grapes, and oil, and garments. All these are for good to the righteous;
So to the sinners they are turned to evil. There are spirits that are created for punishment,
Who in their wrath lay on many strokes; In the time of destruction they pour out their strength, And appease the wrath of He who made them. Fire, and hail, and scarcity of food, and death,
All these were created for punishment; Teeth of wild beasts, and scorpions,
serpents, And the sword punishing the wicked to destruction. They shall rejoice in His Command, and they shall
be ready upon earth when needed; 1191
And thought upon these, and have left them in writing. All the works of HWHY are good;
And He shall give all that is needed in due season; So that a man cannot say, “This is worse than
that.” For in time they all shall be prove good; And therefore praise HWHY with all your heart and
voice, And baraḵ the Name of HWHY.

Great hardship is created for every man, And a heavy yoke is upon the sons of Aḏam; From the day that they go out of their mother’s womb, Till the day that they return to the mother of all. Their imagination of what is to come, and the day
of death, Are their thoughts, and fear of heart; From he who sits on a throne of esteem,
To he who is humbled in dirt and ashes; From he who wears purple and a crown,
To he who is clothed with a linen robe. Wrath, and envy, trouble, and unrest, fear of
death, and displeasure, and strife, And in the time of rest on his bed his sleep at night changes his knowledge. He gets little or no rest, and after his sleep, is as
in a day of watching, Troubled in the vision of his mind, as if he had escaped out of a battle. When all is safe, he wakes,
And marvels that the fear was naught. These come to all flesh, both man and beast,
And seven times more upon sinners. 1192
Calamities, scarcity of food, distress, and the scourge; These are created for the wicked,
And the flood came for their sakes. All that are of the earth shall return to the earth
again; And that which is of the waters returns to the sea. All bribery and unrighteousness shall be blotted
out; But right-dealing endures forever. The goods of the unrighteous shall be dried up
like a wadi, And shall vanish with noise, like great thunder in rain. While the generous shall rejoice;
So transgressors shall come to naught. The children of the wicked shall not bring forth
many branches; But are as unclean roots on a hard rock. The weed growing on all water and riverbank,
Shall be pulled up before any grass. Kindness is like a most fruitful garden,
And favour endures forever. To labour, and to be content with what a man has,
is a sweet life; But he who finds a treasure is above them both. Children and the building of a city continue a
man’s name; But a blameless wife is counted above them both. Wine and music rejoice the heart;
But the love of wisdom is above them both. The flute and the harp make a sweet melody;
But a pleasant tongue is above them both. Your eye desires favour and loveliness;
But more than both is grain while green. A friend and companion never meet wrongfully;
But above both is a wife with her husband. 1193
But kind deeds shall deliver more than them both. Gold and silver make a solid footing;
But counsel is esteemed above them both. Wealth and power lift the heart;
But the reverence of HWHY is above them both. There is no lack with the reverence of HWHY, And with it you need not seek help. The reverence of HWHY is a fruitful garden,
And covers him above all esteem. My son, do not lead a beggar’s life;
For better it is to die than to beg. The life of he who depends on another man’s
table, Cannot be considered a life; For he pollutes himself with the food of other men; But a wise, disciplined man guards himself from it. Begging is sweet in the mouth of the shameless;
But in his inward parts a fire burns.

O death, how bitter is the remembrance of you to a man that lives at rest in his possessions, To the man who has no pain unto him, and that has prosperity in all; Even to he who is yet able to gain food! 2 O death, your lot is acceptable to the needy, And to him whose strength fails, that is now in the last age, and pained with all, And to he who despairs, and has lost patience! 3 Do not fear the lot of death; Remember those who have been before you, and who come after; For this is the lot from HWHY over all flesh. 4 And why are you against the decision of the Most High? There is no searching in the grave, 1194
Of these matters do not be ashamed, and allow no one to sin by them: Of the Law of the Most High, and His Covenant;
And of judgment to declare the wicked right; Of reckoning with your partners and travellers;
Or of the gift of the inheritance of friends; Of exactness of balance and weights;
Or of acquiring much or little; And of the haughty selling by merchants;
Of much correction of children; And to draw blood from the back of a wicked servant. Where a wicked wife is, safe- keeping is good;
And shut up, where many hands are. Deliver all by number and weight;
And put in writing all that you give out, or receive in. 1196
foolish, And the very old who contends with those who are young; Thus you shall be truly learned, and approved of all men living. The father wakes for the daughter, when no man
knows; And the concern for her takes away sleep - When she is young, lest she pass the flower of youth; And being married, lest she should be hated; In her maidenhood, lest she should be defiled and
become pregnant in her father’s house; And having a husband, lest she should misbehave herself; And when she is married, lest she should be barren. Keep a close watch over a shameless daughter,

Lest she make you a laughing-stock to your enemies, And a byword in the city, and a reproach among the people, And make you ashamed before the assembly. Do not look upon the loveliness of every woman,
And do not sit in the midst of women. For a moth comes from garments, and
wickedness from women. Better is the hardness of a man than a courteous
woman, A woman who brings shame and reproach. I shall now remember the works of HWHY, and
declare that which I have seen: In the Words of HWHY are His works, And all His creation does His desire. The sun that gives light looks upon all,
And its doing is full of the esteem of HWHY.
declare all of His marvellous works, Which HWHY the Almighty firmly settled, 1197
considers their crafty schemes; For HWHY knows all that may be known, And He looks upon the signs of the world. He declares matters that are past, and those to
come, And reveals the path of that which is hidden. No thought escapes Him,
Nor is any word hidden from Him. He has adorned the excellent works of His
wisdom, And He is from everlasting to everlasting: Unto Him none is added, nor shall He be diminished, And He has no need of any counsellor. Oh how desirable are all His works!
And that a man may see even a spark. All these live and remain forever for all uses,
And they are all obedient. All matters are equal, one against another;
And He has made none imperfect. One establishes the good of another;
And who is ever filled with looking upon His esteem?
The pride of the heights, the clear expanse, The loveliness of the shamayim, with His esteemed display; The sun when it appears, showing a marvellous
instrument at its rising; The work of the Most High. At noon it scorches the land,
And who shall stand its burning heat? A man blowing a furnace works with heat,
But the sun burns the mountains three times more; Breathing out fiery vapours, and sending out bright rays, it blinds the eyes. 1198
And at His command it runs speedily. He made the moon also to serve in its season for
appointed times, And a sign for the world. From the moon is the sign of Feasts,
A light that decreases in its completion. The new moon is called after its name,
Increasing wondrously in its changing, being an instrument for the hosts above, Shining in the expanse of the shamayim; The loveliness of the shamayim, the esteem of the
stars, An ornament giving light in the highest places of HWHY. At the command of the Qadosh One they stand in
their order, And never weary in their watches. Look upon the rainbow, and praise He who made
it; It is very lovely in its brightness. It surrounds the shamayim with a splendid arc,
And the hands of the Most High have bent it. By His command He makes the snow to fall in
place, And sends the lightnings of His judgment swiftly. Through this the storehouses are opened;
And clouds fly onward as birds. By His great power He makes the clouds pour out,
And the hailstones are broken small. At His sight the mountains are shaken,
And at His desire the south wind blows. The noise of thunder causes the earth to tremble;
So does the northern storm and the whirlwind. As birds flying He scatters the snow, And its falling is as the settling of grasshoppers. 1199
And the heart is astonished at its falling. He also pours the frost as salt upon the earth,
And being hardened, it lays on the top as sharp icicles. When the cold north wind blows, and the water is
hardened into ice, It remains upon every collection of water, And clothes the water like a breastplate. It devours the mountains, and burns the
wilderness, And consumes the grass like fire. A mist coming speedily stands as a healer of all,
A refreshing dew coming after heat. By His counsel He calms the deep,
And plants islands within it. Those who sail on the sea tell of its dangers;
And when we hear it with our ears, we marvel at it. For in it are strange and wondrous works,
Differing kinds of all creatures and whales created. By Him the end of them has a benefit of good,
And by His word all exists. We may speak much, and yet come short;
Therefore in summary, He is all. How are we able to exalt Him?
For He is great above all His works. HWHY is awesome and exceedingly great,
And His power is marvellous. When you esteem HWHY, exalt Him as much as
you may; For He shall even yet far exceed. And when you exalt Him, deliver all your strength, And do not be weary; for you shall never declare enough. Who has seen Him, that he might tell us?
And who could exalt Him as He is? 1200
hidden, For we have seen but a few of His works. For HWHY has made all;
And to the reverent has he given wisdom.
Let us now baraḵ men of name, And our fathers who brought us forth. HWHY has worked great esteem by them,
Through His great power from the beginning. Those who ruled in their reigns, men named for
their strength, Giving counsel by their understanding, and declaring neḇuoth. Leaders of the people by their counsels;
And by their knowledge of learning, fitting for the people, Wise and learned are their instructions. Such who compose musical songs, and speak
verses in writing; Wealthy men equipped with resource, living
peaceably in their dwellings; All these were esteemed in their generations,
And were the esteem of their times. There are some of them who have left behind a
name, That their bireḵoth might be declared. And there are some who have no remembrance;
Who have perished as though they had never been; And have become as though they had never been born; And their children after them. But these were kind men,
Whose righteousness has not been forgotten. With their seed a good inheritance shall
continually remain, And their children are within the Covenant. 1201
And their children for their sakes. Their seed shall remain forever,
And their esteem shall not be blotted out. Their bodies are buried in peace;
But their name lives forever. The people shall tell of their wisdom,
And the assembly shall declare their praise. Ḥanoḵ pleased HWHY and was translated,
Being an example of repentance to all generations. Noaḥ was found perfect and righteous;
In the time of wrath he was taken in exchange; Therefore he was left as a remnant upon the earth when the flood came. An everlasting Covenant was made with him,
That no longer would all flesh perish by the flood. Aḇraham was a great father of many people;
There was none like him in esteem; Who kept the Law of the Most High, and was in
Covenant with Him. He established the Covenant in his flesh; And when he was tried, he was found trustworthy. Therefore He assured him with an oath,

That He would baraḵ the nations in his seed, And that He would multiply him as the dust of the earth, And exalt his seed as the stars, and cause them to inherit from sea to sea, And from the River unto the utmost part of the land. With Yitsḥaq He likewise established the beraḵah

of all men, and the Covenant, And caused it to rest upon the head of Ya’aqoḇ. He acknowledged him with His beraḵah, And gave him an inheritance, and divided his portions; Among the twelve tribes He divided them. 1202
And He brought out from him a kind man, who found favour in the sight of all flesh, Even Mosheh, beloved of Elohim and men, whose remembrance is baruḵ.
And exalted him, so that his enemies stood in fear of him. By his words He caused the wonders to cease,
And He made him esteemed in the sight of sovereigns, And gave him a Command for His people, And showed him part of His esteem. He qadosh him in his trustworthiness and humility,
And chose him out of all men. He caused him to hear His voice, and brought him
into the thick cloud, And gave him Commands before His face, Even the Law of Ḥai and knowledge, That he might teach Ya’aqoḇ His Covenant, And Yisra’ĕl his Right-Rulings.
Even his brother, of the tribe of Lĕwi. He made an everlasting Covenant with him,
And gave him the kehunnah among the people; He adorned him with comely ornaments, And clothed him with a robe of esteem. He put upon him perfect esteem;
And strengthened him with splendid garments, With linen trousers, with a long robe, and the shoulder garment. And He surrounded it with pomegranates,
And with many golden bells all around, So that as he walked there would be a sound, And a noise made that would be heard in the Hĕyḵal, For a remembrance to the children of His people; 1203
purple, The work of embroidery with a breastplate of Right- Ruling, And with Urim and Tummim; With woven scarlet, the work of the skilled

workman, With precious stones engraved like seals, and mounted in gold, The work of the engraver with writing engraved for a remembrance, After the number of the tribes of Yisra’ĕl. He placed a crown of gold upon the turban, in
Nor did any stranger ever put them on, But only his children and his children’s children for all time. Their offerings shall be completely consumed
twice every day continually. Mosheh ordained him, and anointed him with
slaughterings to HWHY, Incense, and a sweet savour, for a remembrance, To make atonement for His people. He gave him His Commands, and authority in the
Laws of Right-Rulings, 1204
And scorned him in the wilderness, Even the men that were on the side of Dathan and Aḇiram, And the assembly of Qoraḥ, with rage and wrath. This HWHY saw, and it displeased Him,
And in His wrathful displeasure they were consumed; He did wonders upon them, to consume them with the fiery flame. But he made Aharon more esteemed,
And gave him an inheritance, and divided to him the first-fruits of the increase; Most of all He prepared bread in abundance; For they eat of the offerings of HWHY,
Which He gave to him and his seed. However in the land of the people he had no
inheritance, Nor had he any portion among the people; For HWHY Himself is his portion and inheritance. The third in esteem is Pineḥas the son of Eli’ezer,
Because he had ardour in the reverence of HWHY, And stood up with good courage of heart when the people were turned back, And made atonement for Yisra’ĕl. Therefore there was a Covenant of peace made
with him, That he should be the chief of the Miqdash and of His people, And that he and his descendants should have the height of the kehunnah forever; According to the Covenant made with Dawiḏ son
of Yishai, of the tribe of Yahuḏah, That the inheritance of the sovereign should be to his descendants alone; 1205
rule His people in righteousness, That their good is not abolished, and that their esteem may endure forever.

Yahoshua the son a Nun was a brave warrior, And was the successor of Mosheh in neḇuoth, Who according to his name was made great for the saving of the elect of Elohim, And taking vengeance on the enemies that rose up against them, That he might place Yisra’ĕl in their inheritance. What great esteem he attained, when he lifted up
his hands, And stretched out his sword against the cities! Who before him ever stood up to it? For HWHY
Himself brought his enemies to him. Did the sun not go back by His doing?
And was not one day as long as two? He called upon the Most High Ĕl, when the
enemies pressed upon him on every side; And HWHY the Almighty heard him. And with hailstones of great strength He made the

battle fall violently against the nations, And at the descent he destroyed those who resisted, That the nations might know all their strength, Because he fought in the sight of HWHY, And he followed the Almighty. In the time of Mosheh he also did a work of
kindness, He and Kalĕḇ the son of Yephunneh, In that they withstood the assembly, And withheld the people from sin, and appeased the wicked murmuring. 1206
These two were preserved to bring them into the inheritance, Even to the land that flows with milk and honey. HWHY also gave strength to Kalĕḇ,
Who remained with him to his old age; So that he entered into the high places of the land, And his seed obtained it for an inheritance; That all the children of Yisra’ĕl might see that it is
good to follow HWHY.
Whose heart did not go whoring, nor departed from HWHY, Let their memory be baruḵ. Let their bones flourish from their place,
And let the name of those who were esteemed be continued upon their children. Shemu’ĕl, the naḇi of HWHY, beloved of his Aḏon,
Established a reign, and anointed princes over His people. By the Law of HWHY he rightly-ruled the assembly,
And HWHY showed respect toward Ya’aqoḇ. By his trustworthiness he was found a true naḇi,
And by his word he was known to be trustworthy in vision. He called upon HWHY the Almighty,
When his enemies pressed upon him on every side, When he offered the suckling lamb. And HWHY thundered from the shamayim,
And with a great noise made His voice heard. And He destroyed the rulers of the Tsorites,
And all the princes of the Pelishtites. And before his long sleep he bore witness in the
sight of HWHY and His anointed, “I have not taken any man’s goods, so much as a shoe.” And no man accused him. 1207
sovereign his end, And lifted up his voice from the earth in neḇuah, To blot out the wickedness of the people.
And after him rose up Nathan to naḇa in the time of Dawiḏ. As the fat is taken away from the peace offering,
So Dawiḏ was chosen out of the children of Yisra’ĕl. He played with lions as with young goats,
And bears as with lambs. Did he not slay a giant, when he was still young?
And did he not take away the reproach of the people, When he lifted up his hand with the stone in the sling, And beat down the boasting of Golyath? For he called upon the Most High Ĕl;
And He gave him strength in his right hand to slay that mighty warrior, And raise up the horn of His people. So the people esteemed him with ten thousands,
And praised him with the bireḵoth of HWHY, In that He gave him a crown of esteem. For he destroyed their enemies on every side,
And brought to naught his adversaries, the Pelishtites, And broke their horn in pieces to this day. In all his works he praised the Qadosh One Most
High with words of esteem; With his whole heart he sang songs, And loved He who made him. He also appointed singers before the altar,
That with their voices they made sweet melody, And sang praises daily with their songs. He adorned their Feasts, and put in order the
Appointed Times until the end,
forever: He gave him a Covenant of sovereigns, And a throne of esteem in Yisra’ĕl. After him rose up a wise son, and for his sake his
dwelling was broad. Shelomoh reigned in a peaceable time, and was
esteemed; For Elohim made quiet all around him, That he might build a House for His Name, And prepare His Miqdash forever. How wise you were in your youth,
And filled with understanding as a flood! Your being covered the whole earth, and you filled
it with deep parables. Your name went to the far islands;
And for your peace you were loved. The lands marvelled at you for your songs, and
HWHY Elohim of Yisra’ĕl, You gathered gold as tin and multiplied silver as lead. You bowed your loins to women,
And by your body you were brought into subjection. You stained your esteem, and polluted your seed;
So that you brought wrath upon your children, And were grieved for your folly. So the reign was divided, and out of Ephrayim
ruled a rebellious reign. But the kindness of HWHY shall never cease,

Nor shall any of His works perish, Neither shall He cut off the descendants of His elect, And the seed of he who loves Him He shall not take away; Therefore He gave a remnant to Ya’aqoḇ, And out of him, a root of Dawiḏ. 1209

And of his seed he left behind him Reḥaḇ’am, Even the foolishness of the people, and one who had no understanding, Who turned the people away through his counsel. There was also Yaroḇ’am the son of Neḇat, Who caused Yisra’ĕl to sin, and showed Ephrayim the way of sin; And their sins were multiplied exceedingly,
So they were driven out of the land. For they sought out all wickedness,
Till the punishment came upon them.
Then Ĕliyahu the naḇi stood up as fire, And his word burned like a lamp. He brought a severe scarcity of food upon them,
And by his ardour he diminished their number. By the word of HWHY he shut up the shamayim,
And also brought down fire three times. O Ĕliyahu, how you were esteemed in your
wondrous deeds! And whose esteem is like yours? Who raised up a dead man from death,
And his being from the place of the dead, By the word of the Most High; Who brought sovereigns to destruction,
And honourable men from their bed; Who heard the rebuke of HWHY at Sinai,
And the judgment of punishment in Ḥorĕḇ; Who anointed sovereigns to take vengeance,
And neḇi’im to succeed after him; Who was taken up in a whirlwind of fire,
And in a chariot of fiery horses; Who were ordained for reproofs in their times,
To appease the wrath of judgment of HWHY, Before it broke forth into wrath, 1210
For we shall surely live. It was Ĕliyahu who was covered with a whirlwind;
And Ĕlisha was filled with His Ruaḥ. While he lived, he was not moved by the presence of any prince, Nor could any bring him into subjection. No word could overcome him;
And after his death his being naḇa. He did wonders in his life,
And at his death his works were marvellous. For all this the people did not repent,

Nor did they depart from their sins, Till they were plundered and carried out of their land, And were scattered through all the earth; Yet there remained a remnant of the people, And a ruler from the house of Dawiḏ; Of whom some did that which was pleasing to
Elohim, And some multiplied sins. Ḥizqiyahu fortified his city, and brought in water
into the midst of it; He dug the solid rock with tools of iron, And made wells for water. In his time Sanḥĕriḇ came up, and sent the
Raḇshaqĕh, And lifted up his hand against Tsiyon, And boasted proudly. Then their hearts and hands trembled,
And they were in pain, as women in childbirth. But they called upon HWHY who is kind,
And stretched out their hands toward Him. And immediately the Qadosh One heard them out of the shamayim, And delivered them by the service of Yeshayahu. 1211
And His messenger destroyed them. For Ḥizqiyahu had done that which pleased HWHY,
And was strong in the Ways of Dawiḏ his father, As Yeshayahu the naḇi, who was great and trustworthy in his vision, had commanded him. In his time the sun went backward,
And he lengthened the sovereign’s life. He saw by an excellent spirit what would come to
pass, And he comforted those who mourned in Tsiyon. He showed what should come to be at the end of
time, And secrets before they came to be.

The remembrance of Yoshiyahu is like the composition of a perfume that is made with the skill of the perfumer; It is sweet as honey in all mouths, And as music at a feast of wine. He acted uprightly by instructing the people,
And took away the wicked abominations. He directed his heart toward HWHY,
And in the time of the wicked he established the worship of Elohim. All except Dawiḏ and Ḥizqiyahu and Yoshiyahu,
were wicked; For they forsook the Law of the Most High, Even the sovereigns of Yahuḏah failed. Therefore He gave their strength to others,
And their esteem to a foreign nation. They burned the chosen city of the Miqdash,
And made the streets desolate, According to the neḇuah of Yirmeyahu. For they treated him evilly, who was yet a naḇi,
qadosh in his mother’s womb, 1212
Which was shown to him upon the chariot of the keruḇim. For he remembered the enemies under the sign of
rain, And directed those who went rightly. And of the twelve neḇi’im let their remembrance
be baruḵ, And let their bones flourish again out of their place; For they comforted Ya’aqoḇ, and delivered them with true expectancy. How shall we exalt Zerubbaḇel?
Even he was as a signet on the right hand; So was Yĕshua son of Yotsaḏaq;
Who in their time built the House,
Whose name is great, who raised up for us the walls that had fallen, And put up the gates and the bars, and raised up our ruins again. But no man on the earth was created like Ḥanoḵ;
For he was taken from the earth. Neither was there a young man born like Yosĕph,
A governor over his brothers, a support to the people, Whose bones were regarded by HWHY. Shĕm and Shĕth were in great esteem among
men, And so was Aḏam above every living creature in creation.
Shim’on the kohĕn ha’gadol, the son of Onyah, Who in his life repaired the House again, And in his days fortified the Hĕyḵal; 1213
was built, The high fortress of the wall around the Hĕyḵal; In his days the cistern to receive water, being
surrounded as the sea, Was covered with plates of bronze; He looked after of the Hĕyḵal that it should not fall,
And fortified the city against a siege. How esteemed he was in the midst of the people,
When coming out of the Miqdash! He was as the morning star in the midst of a
cloud, And as the moon in its fullness; As the sun shining upon the Hĕyḵal of the Most
High, And as the rainbow giving light in the bright clouds, And as the flower of roses in the spring of the
year; As lilies by the rivers of water, And as the branches of frankincense in the time of summer; As fire and incense in the fire holder,
And as a vessel of beaten gold mounted with all kinds of precious stones; And as a fair olive tree budding forth fruit,
And as a cypress which grows up to the clouds. When he put on the robe of esteem,
And was clothed with the perfection of esteem,
kohenim, He himself stood by the hearth of the altar, Surrounded as a young cedar in Leḇanon; And as palm trees they surrounded him. 1214
And the offerings of HWHY in their hands, Before all the assembly of Yisra’ĕl. And finishing the service at the altar,
That he might adorn the offering of the Most High Almighty, He stretched out his hand to the cup,
And pouring the blood of the grape, He poured out at the foot of the altar, A sweet fragrance to the Most High Sovereign of all. Then the sons of Aharon shouted,
And sounded the silver trumpets, And made a great noise to be heard, For a remembrance before the Most High. Then all the people hurried together,
And fell down on their faces on the earth to worship HWHY Ĕl Shaddai, the Most High. The singers also sang praises with their voices,
With all kinds of sounds sweet melody was made. And the people sought HWHY the Most High,
By prayer before He who is kind,
the whole assembly of the children of Yisra’ĕl, To give the beraḵah of HWHY with his lips, and to rejoice in His Name. And they bowed themselves down to worship a
second time, That they might receive a beraḵah from the Most High. Now therefore baraḵ the Elohim of all,
Who does only wondrously everywhere, Who exalts our days from the womb, And deals with us according to His kindness. He gives joy to the heart,
And that peace may be in our days in Yisra’ĕl forever; 1215
And deliver us in His time! There are two manner of nations which my heart
abhors, And the third is no nation: Those who sit on the mountain of Shomeron,
And those who dwell among the Pelishtites, And those foolish people who dwell in Sheḵem. Yahoshua the son of Sira of Yerushalayim,
Has written in this book the instruction of understanding and knowledge, From whose heart poured out wisdom. Baruḵ is he who shall be exercised in these;
And he who treasures them up in his heart shall become wise. For if he does them, he shall be strong in all;
For the light of HWHY leads he who gives wisdom to the reverent. Baruḵ be the Name of HWHY forever. Amĕn, Amĕn.
A Prayer of Yahoshua the son of Sira. I thank you, O Aḏon and Sovereign,
And praise You, O Elohim my Saviour; I give praise to Your Name; For You are my Defender and Helper,

And have preserved my body from destruction, And from the snare of the slanderous tongue, And from the lips that forge lies, And have been my Helper against my adversaries; And have delivered me, according to the multitude

of Your kindnesses and greatness of Your Name, From the teeth of those who were ready to devour me, And out of the hands of those who sought after my life, And from the great afflictions which I had; 1216
And from the midst of the fire which I did not kindle; From the depth of the inward parts of She’ol,
From an unclean tongue, and from lying words. By an accusation to the sovereign from an
unrighteous tongue, My being drew near unto death, My life was near to She’ol beneath. They surrounded me on every side,
And there was no one to help me. I looked for the support of men, but there was none. Then I thought upon Your favour, O HWHY,
And prayed for deliverance from death, I called upon Aḏonai HWHY, the Father,
That He would not leave me in the days of my trouble, And in the time of the proud, when there was no help. I praise Your Name continually,
And sing praises with thanksgiving; And so my prayer is heard. For You saved me from destruction,
And delivered me from the evil time; Therefore I thank and praise You, And baraḵ Your Name, O HWHY! When I was still young, or if I ever went travelling,
I desired wisdom openly in my prayer. I prayed for her before the Hĕyḵal,
And shall seek her to the end. Even from the flower till the grape was ripe,
My heart has delighted in her; My foot went the right way, From my youth upward I sought after her. 1217
And acquired much learning. I profited in this, therefore I shall ascribe esteem
to He who gives me wisdom. For I purposed to go after her,
And earnestly I followed that which is good; So I shall not be ashamed. My being has wrestled with her,
And in my doings I was exact. I stretched forth my hands to the shamayim above, And bewailed my ignorances of her. I directed my being unto her,
And I found her in pureness. I have had my heart joined with her from the beginning, Therefore I shall not be forsaken. My heart was troubled in seeking her;
Therefore I have received a good possession. HWHY has given me a tongue for my reward,
And I shall praise Him with it! Draw near unto me, you unlearned,
And dwell in the house of learning. Why are you slow, and what do you say to these?
Seeing your beings are very thirsty. I opened my mouth, and said,
“Acquire her for yourselves without silver.” Put your neck under the yoke, and let your being
receive instruction; She is found to be close at hand. See with your eyes, how I have only little labour,
And have received much rest. Acquire learning with a great sum of silver,
And get much gold by her. Let your being rejoice in His kindness,
And do not be ashamed of His praise. Work your work early,
And in His time He shall give you your reward. 1218

In the twelfth year of the reign of Neḇuḵaḏnetstsar, who reigned in Ninewĕh, the great city; in the days of Arpaḵshaḏ, who reigned over the Maḏites in Aḥmetha, and in Aḥmetha built walls round about of stones
hewn three ammah wide and six ammah long, and made the height of the wall seventy ammah, and the breadth of it fifty ammah, and put its towers upon its gates a hundred ammah
high, and its breadth in the foundation sixty ammah. And he made its gates, even gates that were raised
to the height of seventy ammah, and the breadth of them was forty ammah, for the going forth of his mighty armies, and for the formation of his footmen. Also in those days, sovereign Neḇuḵaḏnetstsar
fought against overeign Arpaḵshaḏ in the great plain, which is the plain in the borders of Rhaḡes. And all those who dwelt in the hill country, and all

who dwelt by Perath came to him, and Ḥiddeqel and Hudaspĕs, and the plain of Aryoḵ the sovereign of the Ĕylamites, and very many nations of the sons of Kasdim, assembled themselves to the battle. Then Neḇuḵaḏnetstsar sovereign of Ashshur sent

to all who dwelt in Paras, and to all who dwelt westward, and to those who dwelt in Kilikia, and Dammeseq, and Leḇanon, and opposite Leḇanon, and to all who dwelt on the seacoast, and to those among the nations that were of
Karmel, and Gil’aḏ, and the higher Galil, and the great Valley of Yizre’ĕl, and to all that were in Shomeron and its cities, and
beyond the Yardĕn to Yerushalayim, and Bĕyth Anun, and Ḥĕlets, and Qaḏĕsh, and the River of Mitsrayim, 1219
the inhabitants of Mitsrayim, until you come to the borders of Kush. But all the inhabitants of the land disregarded the

command of Neḇuḵaḏnetstsar sovereign of Ashshur, neither went with him to battle, for they were not afraid of him. Indeed, he was before them as one man, and they sent away his ambassadors from them without effect, and with shame. Therefore Neḇuḵaḏnetstsar was very wroth with all

this land, and swore by his throne and reign, that he would surely be avenged upon all those coasts of Kilikia, and Dammeseq, and Aram, and that he would slay all the inhabitants of the land of Mo’aḇ with the sword, and the children of Ammon, and all Yahuḏah, and all who were in Mitsrayim, till you come to the borders of the two seas. Then he marched in battle array with his strength

against sovereign Arpaḵshaḏ in the seventeenth year, and he prevailed in his battle; for he overthrew all the strength of Arpaḵshaḏ, and all his horsemen, and all his chariots. And became master of his cities, and came to
Aḥmetha, and took the towers, and plundered its streets, and turned its pleasantness into shame. He also took Arpaḵshaḏ in the mountains of
Rhaḡes, and smote him through with his arrows, and utterly destroyed him that day. So afterward he returned to Ninewĕh, both he and
all his army of assorted nations - being a very great number of men of battle - and there he took his ease, and feasted, both he and his army, a hundred and twenty days. 1220

And in the eighteenth year, the twenty-second day of the first month, it was spoken in the house of Neḇuḵaḏnetstsar sovereign of Ashshur that he should, as he said, avenge himself on all the earth. So he called all his officers to him, and all his
nobles, and spoke with them his secret counsel, and decided upon afflicting the whole earth out of his own mouth. Then they decreed to destroy all flesh, that did not
obey the command from his mouth. And when he had ended his counsel,
Neḇuḵaḏnetstsar sovereign of Ashshur called Holophernĕs the chief captain of his army, who was next to him, and said to him. “Thus said the great sovereign, the master of the

whole earth, ‘See, you shall go out from my presence, and take men with you that trust in their own strength: one hundred and twenty thousand footmen; and the number of twelve thousand horses with their riders. ‘And you shall go against all the western land,
because they disobeyed my command. ‘And you shall declare to them that they prepare for

me earth and water; for I shall go forth in my wrath against them and shall cover the whole face of the earth with the feet of my army, and I shall give them for a plunder, so that their slain shall fill their valleys and wadis
and the river shall be filled with their dead, till it overflows. ‘And I shall lead them captive to the farthest parts
of all the earth. ‘You therefore shall go out beforehand and take for
me all their coasts; and if they surrender themselves to you, you shall reserve them for me till the day of their punishment. 1221
spare them; but put them to the slaughter, and plunder them wherever you go. ‘For as I live, and by the power of my reign,
whatever I have spoken, that I shall do by my hand. ‘And take heed that you transgress none of the
commands of your master, but accomplish them fully, as I have commanded you, and do not delay to do them.’ ” Then Holophernĕs went out from the presence of
his master, and called all the governors and captains and the officers of the army of Ashshur; and he mustered the chosen men for the battle, as
his master had commanded him, to one hundred and twenty thousand, and twelve thousand mounted archers; and he arranged them, as a great army is ordered
for battle. And he took camels and donkeys for their supplies,
a very great number; and sheep and oxen and goats without number for their provisions, and plenty of food for every man of the army, and
very much gold and silver out of the sovereign’s palace. Then he went forth and all his strength to go before
sovereign Neḇuḵaḏnetstsar in the journey, and to cover all the face of the earth westward with their chariots and horsemen and their chosen footmen. A great number of various countries also came with
them like locusts, and like the dust of the earth; for the crowd was without number. And they went forth from Ninewĕh three days’
journey toward the plain of Bĕktilĕth, and pitched from Bĕktilĕth near the mountain which is to the left hand of upper Kilikia. 1222
horsemen and chariots, and went from there into the hill country; and destroyed Put and Luḏ, and plundered all the
children of Rassis, and the Yishma’ĕlites, who were toward the wilderness to the south of the land of the Ḵelleans. Then he passed over Perath, and went through
Aram Naharayim, and destroyed all the high cities that were on the River Aḇrona, till you come to the sea. And he took the borders of Kilikia, and killed all who
resisted him, and came to the borders of Yepheth, which were toward the south, opposite Araḇia. He also surrounded all the children of Miḏian, and
burned up their tents, and plundered their sheepfolds. Then he went down into the plain of Dammeseq in

the time of wheat harvest, and burned up all their fields, and destroyed their flocks and herds, he also plundered their cities and utterly laid waste their lands and smote all their young men with the edge of the sword. Therefore the fear and dread of him fell upon all the
inhabitants of the seacoasts who were in Tsor and Tsiḏon and those who dwelt in Sur and Okeyna, and all who dwelt in Yemna’an; and those who dwelt in Ashdoḏ and Ashqelon feared him greatly.
So they sent ambassadors to him to entreat for peace, saying, “See, we the servants of Neḇuḵaḏnetstsar the great
sovereign lie before you; use us as is good in your eyes. “Look, our houses and all our places and all our
fields of wheat and flocks and herds, and all the camps of our tents lie before you; use them as it pleases you. 1223
servants; come and deal with them as seems good to you.” So the men came to Holophernĕs, and spoke to
him after this manner. Then he came down toward the seacoast, both he
and his army, and appointed garrisons in the high cities, and took chosen men out of them for help. So they and all the country round about received
them with flowers, with dances, and with timbrels. But he broke down their pillars and cut down their

Ashĕrim; for he had decreed to destroy all the mighty ones of the land, that all nations should worship Neḇuḵaḏnetstsar only, and that all tongues and tribes should call upon him as a mighty one. He also came opposite Yizre’ĕl near Yahuḏah,
opposite the great ridge of Yahuḏah. And he camped between Geḇa and Bĕyth She’an,
and there he waited a whole month, that he might gather together all the supplies for his army.

Now the children of Yisra’ĕl who dwelt in Yahuḏah, heard all that Holophernĕs the chief captain of Neḇuḵaḏnetstsar sovereign of Ashshur had done to the nations, and how he had plundered all their temples, and brought them to nought. Therefore they were exceedingly afraid of him, and
were troubled for Yerushalayim, and for the Hĕyḵal of HWHY their Elohim; for they had recently returned from the captivity,
and all the people of Yahuḏah were recently gathered together; and the utensils and the altar and the House were qadosh after they were defiled. So they sent to all the coast of Shomeron, and
Qonah and to Bĕyth Ḥoron, and Ba’al Mayim, and Yeriḥo, and to Ḥoḇah, and Ḥatsor, and to the valley of Shalĕm; 1224
the high mountains, and strengthened the cities that were in them, and laid up food for the supply of battle; for their fields were recently reaped. Also Yoyaqim the kohĕn ha’gadol, who was in

Yerushalayim in those days, wrote to those who dwelt in Bĕyth Yulia, and Bĕyth Hornasthayim, which is opposite Yizre’ĕl toward the open country, near to Dothan, commanding them to guard the passages of the hill

country; for through them there was an entrance into Yahuḏah, and it was easy to stop those who would come up, because the passage was narrow - for two men at the most. And the children of Yisra’ĕl did as Yoyaqim the
kohĕn ha’gadol had commanded them, with the elders of all the people of Yisra’ĕl who dwelt at Yerushalayim. Then every man of Yisra’ĕl cried to Elohim with
great ardour, and they humbled their beings with great fervency; both they and their wives and their children and
their cattle and every stranger and hired man and their servants bought with money, and put sackcloth upon their loins. So every man and woman and the little children and

the inhabitants of Yerushalayim, fell before the Hĕyḵal, and threw ashes upon their heads, and spread out their sackcloth before the face of HWHY; they also put sackcloth around the altar, and cried to the Elohim of Yisra’ĕl all with one
accord earnestly, that He would not give their children as prey and their wives as spoil and the cities of their
their afflictions; for the people fasted many days in all 1225

kohenim that stood before HWHY, and those who served before HWHY, had their loins girded with sackcloth and offered the daily burnt offerings with the vowed and voluntary offerings of the people, and had ashes on their turbans, and cried unto
HWHY with all their strength, that He would look upon all the house of Yisra’ĕl with favour.

Then it was declared to Holophernĕs, the chief captain of the army of Ashshur, that the children of Yisra’ĕl had prepared for battle and had shut up the passages of the hill country and had fortified all the tops of the high hills and had laid obstructions in the plains, with which he was very wroth, and called all the
princes of Mo’aḇ and the captains of Ammon, and all the governors of the seacoast; and he said to them, “Tell me now you sons of

Kena’an, who these people are that dwell in the hill country; and what are the cities that they inhabit and what is the number of their army and in what is their power and strength and what sovereign is appointed over them or captain of their army, and why have they determined not to come and
meet me, more than all the inhabitants of the west?” Then Aḵior, the captain of all the sons of Ammon
said, “Let my master now hear a word from the mouth
because they would not follow the mighty ones of their fathers, who were in the land of Kasdim. “For they left the way of their ancestors and

worshipped the Elohim of the shamayim, the Elohim whom they knew. So they cast them out from the face of their mighty ones, and they fled into Aram Naharayim, and sojourned there many days. “Then their Elohim Commanded them to depart

from the place where they sojourned, and to go into the land of Kena’an; where they dwelt, and increased in gold and silver and with very much cattle. “But when a famine covered all the land of Kena’an,

they went down into Mitsrayim, and sojourned there, while they were provided for, and became a great multitude there, so that none could number their nation. “Therefore the sovereign of Mitsrayim rose up
against them, and dealt cunningly with them, and brought them low in making bricks, and made them slaves. “Then they cried out to their Elohim, and He smote
all the land of Mitsrayim with incurable plagues; so the Mitsrites cast them out of their sight. “And Elohim dried the Sea of Reeds before them,
and brought them to Mount Sinai, and Qaḏĕsh
Barnĕa, and cast out all who dwelt in the wilderness. “So they dwelt in the land of the Amorites, and they
destroyed all those of Ḥeshbon by their strength, and passing over the Yardĕn they took possession of all the hill country. “And they cast out before them the Kena’anites, the
Perizzites, the Yeḇusites, and the Sheḵemites, and all the Girgashites, and they dwelt in that land many days. “And while they did not sin before their Elohim, they
prospered, because the Elohim who hates wickedness was with them. 1227

appointed them, they were destroyed in many heavy battles, and were led captives into a land that was not theirs, and the Hĕyḵal of their Elohim was cast down to the ground, and their cities were taken by their enemies. “But now they have returned to their Elohim and
have come up from the places where they were scattered and have possessed Yerushalayim where

any mistake against this people, and they sin against their Elohim, let us consider that this shall be their ruin, and let us go up, and we shall overcome them. “But if there is no wickedness in their nation, let my
master now pass by, lest their Aḏon defend them, and their Elohim be for them, and we become a reproach before all the world.” And when Aḵior had finished these words, all the

people standing around the tent murmured, and the heads of Holophernĕs and all who dwelt by the seacoast and in Mo’aḇ, said that he should kill him. For they said, “We are not afraid of the face of the
children of Yisra’ĕl! For see, they are a people who have no strength nor power for a mighty battle. “Now therefore master Holophernĕs, we shall go up
and they shall be a prey to be devoured by your entire army!”

And when the uproar from the men that were around the council had ceased, Holophernĕs the chief captain of the army of Ashshur said to Aḵior and all the Mo’aḇites before all the company of other nations, “And who are you Aḵior, and the hired men of
Ephrayim, that you have prophesied this against us today, and have said that we should not go to battle 1228

the face of the earth, and their Elohim shall not deliver them! But we his servants shall destroy them as one man; for they are not able to sustain the might of our horses. “For with them we shall trample them, and their

mountains shall be drunk with their blood and their fields shall be filled with their dead bodies and their footprints shall not be able to stand before us, for they shall utterly perish, said sovereign Neḇuḵaḏnetstsar, master of all the earth! For he said, ‘None of my words shall come to naught.’ “And you, Aḵior, a hired man of Ammon, who has

spoken these words on the day of your punishment, shall see my face no more from this day until I take vengeance on this nation that came out of Mitsrayim. “And then the sword of my army and the number of
those who serve me shall pierce your sides, and you shall fall among their slain when I return. “Now therefore my servants shall take you back
into the hill country, and shall place you in one of the cities of the passages; and you shall not perish, till you are destroyed with
them. “And if you persuade yourself in your mind that they
shall be taken, do not let your face fall. I have spoken it, and none of my words shall come to naught.” Then Holophernĕs commanded his servants who
waited on his tent, to take Aḵior and bring him to Bĕyth Yulia, and deliver him into the hands of the children of Yisra’ĕl. So his servants took him, and brought him out of
the camp into the plain, and they went from the midst 1229

up their weapons and went out of the city to the top of the hill; and every man that used a sling kept them from coming up by slinging stones against them. However, having approached hidden below the hill,
they bound Aḵior and threw him down and left him at the foot of the hill, and returned to their master. But the Yisra’ĕlites descended from their city, and
came to him, and released him, and brought him to Bĕyth Yulia, and presented him to the governors of the city, who in those days were: Uzziyah the son of Miḵah,
of the tribe of Shim’on, and Ḥaḇriyah the son of Othni’ĕl, and Ḥeremyah the son of Malki’ĕl. And they called together all the elders of the city,

and all their youth ran together and their women to the assembly, and they put Aḵior in the midst of all their people. Then Uzziyah asked him about what was done. And he answered and related to them the words of

the council of Holophernĕs, and all the words that he had spoken in the midst of the princes of Ashshur, and all that Holophernĕs had spoken proudly against the house of Yisra’ĕl. Then the people fell down and worshipped Elohim,
and cried out to Elohim saying, “O HWHY Elohim of the shamayim! See their pride
and show favour on our humble nation, and look upon the face of those that are qadosh to You this day.” Then they comforted Aḵior, and praised him
greatly. And Uzziyah took him out of the assembly to his
house, and made a feast for the elders; and they called on the Elohim of Yisra’ĕl all that night for help. 1230

The next day Holophernĕs commanded all his army and all his people who had come to take part, that they should remove their encampment against Bĕyth Yulia, to take the ascents of the hill country beforehand, and to fight against the children of Yisra’ĕl. Then their mighty men removed their camps that

day, and the army of the men of battle was one hundred and seventy thousand footmen and twelve thousand horsemen, besides the baggage and other footmen that were among them - a very great crowd. And they camped in the valley near Bĕyth Yulia by
the spring, and they spread themselves wide over Dothan even to Ba’al Mayim, and in length from Bĕyth Yulia to Yoqne’am, which is opposite Yizre’ĕl. Now when the children of Yisra’ĕl saw the number

of them, they were greatly troubled, and each one said to his neighbour, “Now these men shall lick up the face of the earth; for neither the high mountains nor the valleys nor the hills are able to bear their weight.” Then every man took up his weapons of battle and
when they had kindled fires on their towers, they remained and watched all that night. But on the second day, Holophernĕs led out all his
horsemen in the sight of the children of Yisra’ĕl who were in Bĕyth Yulia, and scouted the ascents to the city and came to the
springs of their waters and took them and placed garrisons of men of battle over them, and he himself returned to his army. Then all the chiefs of the children of Ĕsaw came to
him and all the governors of the people of Mo’aḇ and the captains of the seacoast and said, “Let our master now hear a word, that there shall
not be an overthrow of your army. “For this people of the children of Yisra’ĕl do not
trust in their spears, but in the height of the mountains 1231
them in battle array, and not so much as one man of your army shall perish. “Remain in your camp and keep all the men of your
army, and let your servants take possession of the spring of water which issues from the foot of the mountain, for all the inhabitants of Bĕyth Yulia get their water

there; so thirst shall kill them and they shall give up their city. And we and our people shall go up to the tops of the mountains that are near and shall lay siege to them to watch that none go out of the city. “So they and their wives and their children shall be
consumed with fire and before the sword comes against them, they shall be overthrown in the streets where they dwell. “Thus you shall render them an evil reward;
because they rebelled, and did not meet you peaceably.” And these words pleased Holophernĕs and all his
servants, and he gave orders to do as they had spoken. So the camp of the children of Ammon departed
and with them five thousand of Ashshur, and they encamped in the valley and seized the waters and the springs of water of the children of Yisra’ĕl. Then the children of Ĕsaw went up with the children

of Ammon and encamped in the hill country opposite Dothan. And they sent some of them toward the south and toward the east opposite Aqrabbah, which is near Ḵusi which is on the wadi Moḵmur; and the rest of the army of Ashshur encamped in the plain, and covered the face of the whole land. And their tents and supply wagons were camped forming a very great crowd. 1232
Elohim, because their hearts failed, for all their enemies had surrounded them, and there was no way to escape from among them. So all the army of Ashshur surrounded them thirty-
four days, both their footmen, chariots and horsemen, so that all the containers of water of the inhabitants of Bĕyth Yulia were empty. And the cisterns were emptied and they had no
water to drink their fill for one day; for they gave them drink by measure. Therefore their young children were disheartened,

and their women and young men fainted for thirst and fell down in the streets of the city and by the passages of the gates, and there was no longer any strength in them. Then all the people assembled to Uzziyah and to
the chief of the city, both young men and women and children, and cried with a loud voice, and said before all the elders, “Elohim be judge between us and you; for you have
done us great injury, in that you have not required peace from the children of Ashshur. “For now we have no helper; and Elohim has sold
us into their hands, that we should be cast down before them with thirst and great destruction. “Now therefore summon them to you, and deliver
the whole city for plunder to the men of Holophernĕs, and to all his army. “For it is better for us to be plundered by them, than

to die for thirst; for we shall be his servants, that our beings may live and not see the death of our infants before our eyes, nor our wives nor our children die. “We take the shamayim and the earth to witness
against you, and our Elohim and Aḏon of our fathers, who punishes us according to our sins and the sins of 1233
the midst of the assembly; and they cried out to HWHY Elohim with a loud voice. Then Uzziyah said to them, “Brothers, be of good
courage, let us yet endure five days, in which time HWHY our Elohim may turn His favour toward us; for He shall not utterly forsake us. “And if these days pass, and no help comes for us,
I shall do according to your word.” And he dispersed the people, each one to their own
watch; and they went to the walls and towers of their city and sent the women and children into their houses; and in the city they were brought very low.

Now at that time Yahuḏith heard of this, who was the daughter of Merari, the son of Utz, the son of Yosĕph, the son of Uzzi’ĕl, the son of Elkayah, the son of Ḥananyah, the son of Giḏ’on, the son of Repha’im, the son of Aḥituḇ, the son of Elihu, the son of Eliyaḇ, the son of Nethan’ĕl, the son of Shelumi’ĕl, the son of Tsurishaddai, the son of Yisra’ĕl. And Menashsheh was her husband, of her tribe
and relatives, who died in the barley harvest. For as he stood overseeing those who bound

sheaves in the field, the heat overcame his head, and he fell on his bed and died in the city of Bĕyth Yulia, and they buried him with his fathers in the field between Dothan and Ba’al Me’on. So Yahuḏith was a widow in her house three years
and four months. And she made herself a tent on the top of her
house, and put sackcloth on her loins and wore her widow’s garments. And she fasted all the days of her widowhood,
except the Shabbath, and evenings of the Shabbath, 1234
and her husband Menashsheh had left her gold and silver, and male and female servants, and cattle and lands; and she maintained them. And no one spoke evil of her; for she greatly
revered Elohim. Now when she heard the evil words of the people

against the governor, when they fainted for lack of water; for Yahuḏith had heard all the words that Uzziyah had spoken to them, and that he had sworn to deliver the city to Ashshur after five days; then she sent her female servant who governed all
that she had, to call Uzziyah and Ḥaḇriyah and Ḥeremyah, the elders of the city. And they came to her, and she said to them, “Hear

me now, you governors of the inhabitants of Bĕyth Yulia; for your words that you have spoken before the people this day are not right, regarding this oath which you made and pronounced between Elohim and you, and have promised to deliver the city to our enemies, unless HWHY turns to help you within these days. “And now who are you to try Elohim this day, and
stand in place of Elohim among the children of men? “And now, try HWHY Elohim, but you shall never
know any matter. “For you cannot find the depth of the heart of man,
