it, holds a sceptre, as though it were a judge of the land. It also has in its right hand a dagger and an axe,
but cannot deliver itself from battle and thieves. By this they are known to be no mighty ones;
therefore do not fear them. For as a vessel that a man uses is worth naught

when it is broken; even so it is with their mighty ones. When they are put up in the temple, their eyes are full of dust through the feet of those who come in. And as the doors are secured on every side against

he who offends the sovereign, as though sentenced to death; even so the priests secure their temples with doors, with locks and bars, lest their mighty ones be plundered by robbers. They light them candles, even more than for
themselves, of which they cannot see one. They are as one of the beams of the temple, yet it
is said their hearts are gnawed upon by creeping creatures out of the earth; but when they eat them and their garments, they do not feel it. Their faces are blackened by the smoke that comes
out of the temple. Upon their bodies and heads sit bats, swallows,
and birds, and also the cats. By this you may know that they are no mighty ones;
therefore do not fear them. 1290
lovely, unless they wipe off the tarnish, they shall not shine; for neither did they feel it when they were moulded. Those in which there is no breath are bought for a
very high price. They are borne upon shoulders, having no feet;
thereby they declare to men that they are of no worth. Those who serve them are also ashamed; for if they

fall to the ground at any time, they cannot rise up again by themselves. Nor if one puts them upright, could they move by themselves. Neither, if they are bowed down, could they make themselves straight; but they put gifts before them as to dead men. As for that which is offered to them, their priests sell
and misuse; similarly their wives preserve some of it in salt; but to the poor and helpless they give none of it. Women in monthly separation and women in
childbirth eat their offerings; by these you know that they are not mighty ones. Do not fear them. For how could they be called mighty ones? For
women place meat before the mighty ones of silver, gold, and wood. And the priests sit in their temples, having their
garments torn, and their heads and beards shaven, and their heads bare. They roar and cry before their mighty ones, as men
do at the feast when one is dead. The priests also take off their garments, and clothe
their wives and children. Whether it be evil that one does to them or good,
they are not able to repay it; they could neither appoint a sovereign, nor put him down. In like manner, they neither give wealth nor silver;
though a man makes a vow to them, and does not guard it, they do not require it. 1291
from the mighty. They do not restore sight to a blind man, nor help
any man in his distress. They show no kindness to the widow, nor do good
to the fatherless. Their mighty ones of wood, and which are overlaid
with gold and silver, are like the stones that are hewn out of the mountain; those who worship them shall be put to shame. How should a man then think and say that they are
mighty ones, when even the Kasdites themselves shame them? For if they shall see one dumb who cannot speak,
they bring him and entreat Bĕl that he might speak, as though it were able to understand. Yet they cannot understand this themselves, and
leave them; for they have no knowledge. The women with cords about them also sit in the

byways, burning bran for perfume; but if any of them, drawn by some that passes by, lies with him, she reproaches her companion, that she was not thought as worthy as herself, nor her cord broken. Whatever is done by them is false; how is it then
even thought or said that they are mighty ones? They are made by carpenters and goldsmiths; they
are no other than what the workmen wants them to be. And they themselves who made them do not live
long; how could those which are made by them be mighty ones? For they left lies and reproaches to those who come
after. For when any battle or plague comes upon them,
the priests consult with themselves, where they might hide with them. 1292
mighty ones, which neither save themselves from battle, nor from plague? For seeing they are only of wood, and overlaid with
silver and gold, it shall be known after this that they are false. And it shall clearly appear to all nations and
sovereigns that they are not mighty ones, rather the works of men’s hands, and that there is no work of Elohim in them. Who then does not know that they are not mighty
ones? For neither do they appoint a sovereign in the land,
nor give rain to men. Neither could they judge their own cause, nor are
they able to correct a wrong; for they are as crows between the shamayim and earth. So when fire falls upon the house of mighty ones of
wood, or overlaid with gold or silver, their priests shall flee away and escape; but they themselves shall be burned up like timbers. And they cannot withstand any sovereign or
enemies; how is it then thought or said that they are mighty ones? Neither are those mighty ones of wood and overlaid
with silver or gold able to escape from either thieves or robbers. Whose gold, and silver, and garments with which
they are clothed are taken by those who are strong, and go away with it all; nor are they able to help themselves. Therefore it is better to be a sovereign that shows

his strength, or even a useful vessel in a house, which the owner has use of, than such false mighty ones; or to be a door in a house, to guard such objects within, than such false mighty ones; or a column of wood in a palace, than such false mighty ones. 1293
do their service, are obedient. In like manner the lightning when it breaks is easy
to be seen; and after the same manner the wind blows in every land. And when Elohim commands the clouds to go over
the whole world, they do as they are ordered. And the fire sent from above to consume hills and
woods does as it is commanded; but these are like them neither in appearance nor power. Therefore it is neither to be supposed nor said that
they are mighty ones, seeing they are neither able to judge causes, nor to do good to men. Knowing therefore that they are not mighty ones,
do not fear them, for they neither curse nor baraḵ sovereigns;
neither they show signs in the shamayim among
the gentiles, nor shine as the sun, nor give light as the moon. The beasts are better than they; for they move
under cover and help themselves. It is then by no means apparent to us that they are
mighty ones; therefore do not fear them. For as a scarecrow in a garden of cucumbers
guards naught; so are their mighty ones of wood, laid over with silver and gold. And likewise their mighty ones of wood, and laid
over with silver and gold, are like a thornbush in an orchard, on which every bird perches; as also like a dead body, that is cast into the darkness. And you shall know them to be non mighty ones by
the bright purple that rots upon them; and they themselves afterward shall be consumed, and shall be a reproach in the land. Better therefore is the righteous man that has no
idols; for he shall be far from reproach. 1294

O HWHY, Ĕl Shaddai of our fathers, Aḇraham, Yitsḥaq, and Ya’aqoḇ, and of their righteous seed; who has made the shamayim and earth, with all its adornment; who has bound the sea by the word of Your Command; who has shut up the deep, and sealed it by Your awesome and esteemed Name; whom all men revere, and tremble before Your power. For the greatness of Your esteem is not able to be borne, and Your threatening wrath toward sinners is unbearable; but Your kind promise is immeasurable and unsearchable. For You are the Most High Ĕl, of great compassion, patient, very kind, and grieves of the evils of men. You, O HWHY, according to Your great goodness have promised repentance and forgiveness to those who have sinned against You, and from Your infinite kindnesses have appointed repentance to sinners, that they may be saved. You therefore, O HWHY, who is Elohim of the righteous, have not appointed repentance to the righteous, as to Aḇraham, and Yitsḥaq, and Ya’aqoḇ, who have not sinned against You; but You have appointed repentance to me who is a sinner; for I have sinned above the number of the sands of the sea. My transgressions, O HWHY, are multiplied! My transgressions are multiplied, and I am not worthy to look and see the height of the shamayim for the multitude of my wickednesses. I am bowed down with many iron bands, so that I am unable to lift up my head, neither have any release, for I have provoked Your wrath, and done wickedness before You. I did not do Your desire, neither have I kept Your Commands. I have put up abominations, and have many stumblings. Now therefore I bow the knee of my heart, asking You for favour. I have sinned, O HWHY, I have sinned, and I acknowledge my wickednesses. Therefore, I humbly ask You, forgive me, O HWHY, forgive me, and do not destroy me in my wickedness. 1295
And they walked in the midst of the fire, praising Elohim, and beraḵah HWHY. Then Azaryah stood up, and prayed in this way:
and opening his mouth in the midst of the fire said, “Baruḵ are You, O HWHY Elohim of our fathers! Your
Name is worthy to be praised and esteemed forever, for You are righteous in all that You have done to
us. Indeed, all Your works are true, Your Ways are
from You. “In all matters we have trespassed, and not obeyed
Your Commands, nor guarded them, neither done as You have Commanded us, that it might be well with us. “Therefore all that You have brought upon us, and
every matter that You have done to us, You have done in true right-ruling. “And You delivered us into the hands of lawless
enemies, most hateful forsakers of Elohim, and to an unrighteous sovereign, and the most wicked in all the earth. “And now, we cannot open our mouths; we have
become a shame and a reproach to Your servants, and to those who worship You. “Yet do not deliver us up completely, for Your
Name’s sake, neither annul Your Covenant! “And do not cause Your kindness to depart from us,
for the sake of Aḇraham Your beloved, for the sake of
would multiply their seed as the stars of the shamayim, and as the sand that lies upon the seashore. “For we, O HWHY, have become less than any
nation, and are held under this day in all the earth because of our sins. “Neither is there at this time prince, or naḇi, or
leader, or burnt offering, or slaughtering, or offering, or incense, or place to slaughter before You, and to find favour. “Nevertheless in a repentant heart and a humble
spirit let us be accepted. “As in the burnt offerings of rams and bulls, and as

in ten thousand fat of lambs; so let our slaughtering be in Your sight this day, and grant that we may follow You completely; for those who put their trust in You shall not be put to shame. “And now, we follow You with all our heart, we
revere You, and seek Your face. “Do not put us to shame, but deal with us according
to Your favour, and according to Your many kindnesses. “Deliver us also according to Your marvellous
works, and give esteem to Your Name, O HWHY, and let all those who do evil to Your servants be put to shame; “And let them be put to shame in all their strength
and might, and let their strength be broken. “And let them know that You are Elohim. The only
Elohim! And esteemed over all the earth!” And the sovereign’s servants, that put them in, did
not cease heating the oven with resin, pitch, tow, and kindling, so that the flame gushed out above the furnace
forty-nine ammah. And it passed through, and burned those Kasdites
found around the furnace. 1298

Praise and exalt Him above all forever: For He has delivered us from Gĕy-Hinnom, and saved us from the hand of death, And delivered us out of the midst of the furnace and burning flame: Even out of the midst of the fire He has delivered us. O give thanks to HWHY, because He shows favour:
For his kindness endures forever. O all you that worship HWHY, baraḵ the Elohim of
mighty ones; Praise Him, and give Him thanks; For His kindness endures forever. 1301
And Sovereign Astuages was gathered to his fathers, and Koresh of Paras received his reign. And Dani’ĕl spoke with the sovereign, and was
esteemed above all his friends. Now the Baḇelians had an idol, called Bĕl, and
every day there was spent upon it: twelve large measures of fine flour, and forty sheep, and six vessels of wine. And the sovereign revered it and went daily to
worship it, but Dani’ĕl worshipped his own Elohim. And the sovereign said to him, “Why do you not worship Bĕl?” Who answered and said, “Because I do not worship
idols made with hands, but the living Elohim, who has created the shamayim and the earth, and reigns over all flesh.” Then the sovereign said to him, “Do you not think
that Bĕl is a living mighty one? Do you not see how much he eats and drinks every day?” Then Dani’ĕl smiled, and said, “O sovereign, do not
be deceived; for this is but clay within, and bronze without, and never ate or drank any.” So the sovereign was wroth, and called for his
priests, and said to them, “If you do not tell me who this is that devours these expenses, you shall die! “But if you shall prove that Bĕl devours them, then
Dani’ĕl shall die; for he has spoken blasphemy against Bĕl.” And Dani’ĕl said to the sovereign, “Let it be according to your word.” Now there were seventy priests of Bĕl, besides
their wives and children. And the sovereign went with Dani’ĕl into the temple of Bĕl. 1302
you, O sovereign, place the meat, and prepare the wine, and shut the door firmly and seal it with your own signet. “And tomorrow when you come in, if you do not find
that all has been eaten up, we shall suffer death, or else Dani’ĕl, who speaks falsely against us.” But they gave little regard, for under the table they
had made a secret entrance, by which they entered in continually, and ate these. So when they had gone out, the sovereign placed

food before Bĕl. Now Dani’ĕl had commanded his servants to bring ashes, and they scattered them throughout the whole temple in the presence of the sovereign alone; then they went out, and shut the door, and sealed it with the sovereign’s signet, and so departed. Now in the night, the priests came with their wives
and children, as was their habit, and ate and drank all. And it came to be in the morning, the sovereign
arose, and Dani’ĕl with him. And the sovereign said, “Dani’ĕl, are the seals
whole?” And he said, “Yes, O sovereign, they are whole.” And as soon as he had opened the door, the
sovereign looked upon the table, and cried with a loud voice, “You are great, O Bĕl, and in you is no deceit at all!” Then Dani’ĕl laughed, and held the sovereign that
he should not go in, and said, “See now the pavement, and note well whose footsteps are there.” And the sovereign said, “I see the footsteps of men,
women, and children.” And then the sovereign was wroth, and took the priests, with their wives and children,
who showed him the secret doors, where they came in, and ate that which was on the table. 1303
over to Dani’ĕl’s authority, who destroyed it and its temple. And in that same place there was a great dragon,
which those of Baḇel worshipped. And the sovereign said to Dani’ĕl, “Shall you also
say that this is of bronze? See, he lives, he eats and drinks. You cannot say that he is no living mighty one; therefore worship him.” Then Dani’ĕl said to the sovereign, “I worship HWHY
my Elohim; for He is the living Elohim. “But allow me, O sovereign, and I shall slay this
dragon without sword or staff.” And the sovereign said, “I allow you.” Then Dani’ĕl took pitch and fat and hair, and boiled

them together, and made lumps from it. This he put in the dragon’s mouth, and so the dragon burst open. And Dani’ĕl said, “See, these are the mighty ones you worship.” When those of Baḇel heard this, they were greatly

enraged, and conspired against the sovereign, saying, “The sovereign has become a Yahuḏi, and he has destroyed Bĕl. He has slain the dragon, and put the priests to death.” So they came to the sovereign, and said, “Give us
Dani’ĕl, or else we shall destroy you and your house!” Now when the sovereign saw that they pressed him
greatly, being compelled, he handed Dani’ĕl over to them, who threw him into the lions’ den, where he was six
days. And in the den there were seven lions, and every
day they had given them two carcasses of two sheep; which then were not given to them, with the intent they would devour Dani’ĕl. Now there was among the Yahuḏim, a naḇi called
Ḥaḇaqquq, who had made stew, and had broken 1304
carry the dinner that you have into Baḇel to Dani’ĕl, who is in the lions’ den.” But Ḥaḇaqquq said, “Master, I never saw Baḇel;
neither do I know where the den is.” Then the messenger of HWHY took him by the head,
and carried him by the hair of his head, and through the power of His Ruaḥ placed him in Baḇel over the den. And Ḥaḇaqquq cried, saying, “O Dani’ĕl, Dani’ĕl!
Take the meal which Elohim has sent you.” And Dani’ĕl said, “You have remembered me, O
Elohim, neither have You forsaken those who seek You and love You.” So Dani’ĕl arose, and ate, and the messenger of
HWHY immediately placed Ḥaḇaqquq in his own place again. On the seventh day the sovereign went to mourn
for Dani’ĕl, but when he came to the den, he looked in, and see, Dani’ĕl was sitting! Then the sovereign cried out with a loud voice,
saying, “Great is HWHY, Elohim of Dani’ĕl, and there is none other besides Him!” And he pulled him out, and threw those who were
the cause of his destruction into the den, and they were devoured in a moment before his face. 1305
There dwelt a man in Baḇel, called Yoyaqim, and he took a wife, whose name was Shoshannah,
the daughter of Ḥilqiyahu, a very lovely woman, and one that revered HWHY. Her parents were also righteous, and taught their
daughter according to the Torah of Mosheh. Now Yoyaqim was a very wealthy man, and had a
lovely garden adjoining his house, and the Yahuḏim came to him because he was more esteemed than all others. The same year two of the elders of the people were
had any matter of law came to them. Now when the people departed at noon,
Shoshannah went into her husband’s garden to walk. And the two elders saw her going in every day, and
walking, therefore their lust was inflamed toward her. And they perverted their own mind, and turned
away their eyes, that they might not look to the shamayim, nor remember righteous Right-Rulings. And although they both were smitten with her love,
they dared not show one another his grief, for they were ashamed to admit their lust, that they
desired to have to do with her. Even so, they watched diligently from day to day to
see her. And the one said to the other, “Let us now go home,
for it is mealtime.” So when they were gone out, they parted from one
another, but turning back again they came to the same place. And after that they had asked one another the cause, they acknowledged their lust. They then both 1306
opportune time, she went in as before with only two female servants, and she desired to wash herself in the garden, for it was hot. And there was no one there except the two elders,
that had hidden themselves, watching her. Then she said to her female servants, “Bring me oil
and washing balm, and shut the garden doors, that I may wash myself.” And they did as she asked them, and shut the

garden doors, and went out themselves at private doors to fetch that which she had commanded them; but they did not see the elders, because they were hidden. Now when the female servants had gone out, the
two elders rose up, and ran to her, saying, “See, the garden doors are shut, so that no one see
us, and we are in love with you; therefore consent to us, and lie with us. “If you shall not, we shall witness against you, that
a young man was with you, and that is why you sent away your female servants from you.” Then Shoshannah sighed, and said, “I am trapped
on every side; for if I do this deed, it is death unto me; and if I do not do it I cannot escape your hands. “It is better for me to fall into your hands, and not
do it, than to sin in the sight of HWHY.” With that Shoshannah cried with a loud voice, and
the two elders cried out against her. Then the one ran, and opened the garden door.
So when the servants of the house heard the cry in
the garden, they rushed in at the private door, to see what was done to her. But when the elders had spoken their words, the
servants were greatly ashamed, for there was never such a report made of Shoshannah. 1307
were assembled to her husband Yoyaqim, the two elders also came full of evil intentions against Shoshannah to put her to death, and said before the people, “Send for Shoshannah,
the daughter of Ḥilqiyahu, Yoyaqim’s wife.” And so they sent. So she came with her father and mother, her
children, and all her relatives. Now Shoshannah was a very delicate woman, and
lovely to look at. And these wicked men commanded to uncover her
face - for she was covered - that they might be filled with her loveliness. Therefore her friends and all that saw her wept.
Then the two elders stood up in the midst of the
people, and laid their hands upon her head. And she, weeping, looked up toward the
shamayim, for her heart trusted in HWHY. And the elders said, “As we walked in the garden
alone, this woman came in with two female servants, and shut the garden doors, and sent the female servants away. “Then a young man, who was hid there, came to
her, and lay with her! “Then we that stood in a corner of the garden,
seeing this wickedness, ran toward them. “And when we saw them together, we could not
hold the man, for he was stronger than we, and opened the door, and leaped out. “But having taken this woman, we asked who the
young man was, but she would not tell us! These matters we do witness.” Then the assembly believed them, as they were the
said, “O everlasting Elohim, who knows the secrets, and knows all before they come to be. 1308
against me, and, see, I must die; whereas I never did such matters as these men have maliciously devised against me!” And HWHY heard her voice.
Therefore when she was led to be put to death,

“What do you mean by these words that you have spoken?” So he, standing in the midst of them said, “Are you

have borne false witness against her.” Therefore all the people turned again in haste, and

other, and said to him, “O you seed of Kena’an, and not of Yahuḏah, loveliness has deceived you, and lust has perverted your heart. “Thus have you dealt with the daughters of Yisra’ĕl,

lied against your own head. For the messenger of Elohim waits with the sword to cut you in two, that he may destroy you.” With that, all the assembly cried out with a loud
voice, and praised Elohim, who saves those who trust in Him. And they rose up against the two elders, for Dani’ĕl
had convicted them of false witness by their own mouth. And according to the Torah of Mosheh, they did to
them such as they had maliciously intended to do to their neighbour, and they put them to death. Thus the innocent blood was saved that very day. Therefore Ḥilqiyahu and his wife praised Elohim for
their daughter Shoshannah, with Yoyaqim her husband, and all their relatives, because there was no dishonesty found in her. From that day onward, Dani’ĕl was held in high
regard in the sight of the people. 1310
And Sovereign Aḥashwĕrosh laid compulsory labour on the land and the islands of the sea.

ruled His inheritance. Therefore those days shall be unto them in the
month Aḏar, the fourteenth and fifteenth day of the same month, with an assembly, and joy, and with 1311

In the fourth year of the reign of Ptolemaeus and Cleopatra, Dositheos, who said he was a kohĕn and Lĕwite, and Ptolemaeus his son, brought this letter of Purim, which they said was the same, and that Lusimaḵos the son of Ptolemaeus, that was in Yerushalayim, had interpreted it. In the second year of the reign of Artaḥshashta the
great, on the first day of the month Nisan, Mordeḵai the son of Ya’ir, the son of Shim’i, the son of Qish, of the tribe of Binyamin, had a dream – who was a Yahuḏi, and dwelt in the city of Shushan,
a great man, being an attendant in the sovereign’s court. He was also one of the captives, which
Neḇuḵaḏnetstsar the sovereign of Baḇel carried from Yerushalayim with Yeḵonyah sovereign of Yahuḏah, and this was his dream: See, a noise of uproar, with thunder, and
earthquakes, and disruption in the land! And, see, two great dragons came forth ready to
fight, and their cry was great. And at their cry all nations were prepared for battle,
that they might fight against the righteous people. And see, a day of darkness and gloom, distress and
anguish, affliction and great uproar upon the earth. And the whole righteous nation was troubled,
fearing their own evils, and were prepared to perish. Then they cried to Elohim, and upon their cry, as it
were from a little fountain, a great flood was made, even much water. The light and the sun rose up, and the lowly were
exalted, and devoured the great. Now when Mordeḵai, who had seen this dream,
and what Elohim had determined to do, awoke, he regarded this dream in mind until night, and desired to know it by all means. 1312
And Mordeḵai took his rest in the court with Gabatha and Tharra, the two eunuchs of the sovereign, and guards of the palace. And he heard their schemes, and searched out
their purposes, and learned that they were about to lay hands upon Artaḥshashta the sovereign; and so he informed the sovereign of them. Then the sovereign examined the two eunuchs,
and after they had confessed it, they were hanged. And the sovereign made a record of these matters,
and Mordeḵai also wrote of them. So the sovereign commanded, Mordeḵai to serve
in the court, and for this he rewarded him. However, Haman the son of Hammeḏatha the
Agagite, who was great in esteem with the sovereign, sought to torture Mordeḵai and his people because of the two eunuchs of the sovereign.

The copy of the letters was this: The great Sovereign Artaḥshashta writes these matters to the princes and governors that are under him from Hodu to Kush in a hundred and twenty-seven provinces. After I became ruler over many nations and reigned

over the whole world, not lifted up with presumption of my authority, but carrying myself always with straightness and kindness, I purposed to settle my subjects continually in a quiet life, and make my reign peaceable, and open for passage to the farthest coasts, to renew peace, which is desired of all men. Now when I asked my counsellors how this might

be brought to pass, Haman, who excelled in wisdom among us, and was approved for his continual kindness and steadfast trustworthiness, and had the esteem of the second place in the reign, declared to us, that in all nations throughout the
world there was scattered a certain malicious people, that had Laws contrary to all nations, and continually despised the commands of sovereigns, so that the 1313

alone are continually in opposition to all men, differing in the strange manner of their Laws, and evilly disposed toward our reign, working all the evil they may that our reign may not be firmly established; therefore we have commanded that all those who

are indicated in writing to you by Haman, who is appointed over the affairs, and is next to us, shall be utterly destroyed by the sword of their enemies, with all their wives and children without any kindness or pity, the fourteenth day of the twelfth month Aḏar of this present year. That they, who of old and now also are malicious,
shall in one day with violence go into the grave, and so, from now on cause our affairs to be well settled, and without trouble. Then Mordeḵai thought upon all the works of HWHY,
and made his prayer to Him, saying, “O Aḏonai HWHY, the Sovereign Almighty!
For the whole world is in Your power, and if You have appointed to save Yisra’ĕl, there is none that disputes You. “For You have made the shamayim and earth, and
all the wonders under the shamayim. You are Aḏon of all, and there is none that resists
You, who is HWHY! “You know all, and You know, HWHY, that it was
neither in contempt nor pride, nor for any desire of esteem, that I did not bow down to proud Haman. “For I could have been content for the salvation of
Yisra’ĕl to kiss the soles of his feet with kindness. “But I did this, that I might not prefer the esteem of
man above the esteem of Elohim; neither shall I worship any but You, O Elohim, neither shall I do it in pride. “And now, O HWHY Elohim and Sovereign, spare
Your people, for their eyes are upon us to bring us to 1314
delivered out of Mitsrayim for Yourself. “Hear my prayer, and be kind to Your inheritance.
Turn our sorrow into joy, that we may live, O HWHY, and praise Your Name, and do not destroy the mouths of those who praise you, O HWHY.” All Yisra’ĕl likewise cried most earnestly to HWHY,
because their death was before their eyes.
Sovereigness Estĕr also, being in fear of death, came to HWHY, and laid aside her splendid apparel, and put on the

garments of anguish and mourning. And instead of precious ointments, she covered her head with ashes and dung, and she humbled her body greatly, and all the places of her joy she filled with her torn hair. And she prayed to HWHY Elohim of Yisra’ĕl, saying,
“O Aḏonai, You alone are our Sovereign. Help me, an empty woman, who has no helper but You; for my danger is at my hand!
“From my youth I have heard in the tribe of my

family that You, O HWHY, took Yisra’ĕl from among all people, and our fathers from all their forefathers, for an inheritance forever, and you have performed whatever You promised them. “And now we have sinned before You. Therefore
You have given us into the hands of our enemies, because we worshipped their mighty ones. O
HWHY, You are righteous! “Nevertheless it does not satisfy them that we are
in bitter captivity; but they have vowed to their idols that they shall abolish that which You have
established with Your mouth, and destroy Your inheritance and stop the mouth of those who praise You, and quench the esteem of Your House and of Your altar. 1315
praises to their idols, and to exalt a fleshly sovereign forever. “O HWHY, do not give Your sceptre to those who are
naught, and do not let them laugh at our fall; but turn their scheme upon themselves, and make an example of he who has begun this against us. “Remember O HWHY, make Yourself known in the
time of our affliction, and give me boldness, O Sovereign of the nations, and Aḏon of all power. “Give me eloquent speech in my mouth before the
lion; turn his heart to hate he who fights against us, that there may be an end of him and of all that are like- minded as him. “But deliver us with Your hand, and help me, who
is abandoned, and who has no other help but You. “You know all, O HWHY; You know that I hate the
esteem of the unrighteous, and abhor the bed of the uncircumcised and of all the gentiles. “You know my need; for I abhor the sign of my high

estate, which is upon my head in the days in which I show myself, and that I abhor it as a menstrual cloth, and that I do not wear it when I am alone by myself, and that your female servant has not eaten at
Haman’s table, and that I have not greatly esteemed the sovereign’s feast, nor drunk the wine of the drink offerings. Neither has Your female servant had any joy since
the day that I was brought here to the present, but in You, O HWHY, Elohim of Aḇraham. “You O mighty Elohim above all, hear the voice of
the destitute and deliver us out of the hands of the evil- doers, and deliver me from my fear.
And on the third day, when she had ended her prayers, she put away her mourning garments, and put on her splendid apparel. And being adorned in esteem, after she had called
upon Elohim, who sees all and is Deliverer of all, she took two female servants with her, 1316
and the other followed, bearing up her train.
And she was tanned through the perfection of her
beauty, and her countenance was cheerful and very delightful; but her heart was in anguish for fear. Then having passed through all the doors, she

stood before the sovereign, who sat upon his royal throne, and was clothed with all his splendid robes, all glittering with gold and precious stones; and he was very frightening. Then lifting up his face that shone with splendour,

he looked very fiercely upon her. And the Sovereigness fell down, and went pale and fainted, and bowed herself upon the head of the female servant that went before her. Then Elohim changed the spirit of the sovereign

into compassion, who in alarm leaped from his throne, and took her in his arms till she came to herself again, and comforted her with loving words and said to her, “Estĕr, what is the matter? I am your brother, take
courage. “Though our law is established, you shall not die.
Come near.” And so he held up his golden sceptre, and laid it
upon her neck, and embraced her, and said, “Speak to me.”
Then she said to him, “I saw you, my master, as a
messenger of Elohim, and my heart was troubled for fear of your greatness. “For you are wondrous, master, and your face is full
of favour.” And as she was speaking, she fell down from
faintness. Then the sovereign was troubled, and all his
servants comforted her.
The great Sovereign Artaḥshashta, to the princes and governors of a hundred and twenty-seven provinces from Hodu to Kush, and to all our trustworthy subjects, greetings: 1317
the great bounty of their esteemed princes, the prouder they have grown; and do their best not only to harm our subjects, but
not being able to handle wealth, also undertake to do against those who do good to them! And not only take respect away from among men,

but also lifted up with the esteemed words of wicked men that were never good, they think to escape the judgment of Elohim, who sees all and hates evil. Also often flattering speech of those who are put in

trust to manage the affairs of their friends, has caused many that are in authority to be partakers of innocent blood, and has surrounded them in incurable evils, deceiving with the falsehood and deceit of their evil
disposition the innocence and goodness of princes. Now you may see this, as we have declared, not so

much by ancient histories, as you may, if you search what has been done evilly of late through the corrupt behaviour of those who are unworthily placed in authority. And we must guard for the time to come, that our
reign may be at rest and peaceable for all men, both by changing our purposes, and always rightly
ruling that which is evident with more equal proceeding. For Haman, a Makedonian, the son of
Hammeḏatha, being indeed a foreigner of Parasian blood, and far removed from our goodness, and as a foreigner received by us, had obtained the favour that we show toward every
nation so much, that he was called ‘our father,’ and was continually esteemed by all being the second to the sovereign. But he, not upholding his greatness, went about to
deprive us of our reign and life; having by many crafty deceits also sought from us
the destruction of Mordeḵai, who saved our life, and 1318
friends, to have the reign of Paras transferred to the Makedonians. But we find that the Yahuḏim, whom this wicked
wretch has delivered to utter destruction, are not evildoers, but live by most righteous Laws, and that they are children of the Most High and
Almighty, living Elohim, who has appointed the reign both to us and to our forefathers in the most excellent manner. Therefore you shall do well not to put into action the
letters sent to you by Haman the son of Hammeḏatha, for he who was the worker of these matters, has

been hanged at the gates of Shushan with all his family - Elohim, who rules over all, speedily rendering vengeance to him according to his deeds. Therefore you shall publish the copy of this letter in
all places, that the Yahuḏim may freely live after their own Laws. And you shall aid them, even the same day, being
the thirteenth day of the twelfth month Aḏar, that they may be avenged on those, who in the time of their affliction shall assault them. For Ĕl Shaddai has turned the day to joy for them,
in which the chosen people should have perished. You shall therefore guard it a high day among your
solemn Feasts with all feasting, that both now and hereafter there may be safety for
us and the highly respected of Paras. But to those who conspire against us - a remembrance of destruction. Therefore every city and land whatever, which shall

not do according to these matters, shall be destroyed without kindness with fire and sword, and shall be made not only impassable for men, but also greatly loathed by wild beasts and birds forever. 1319
And Yoshiyahu held the Feast of the Pesaḥ in Yerushalayim to his Aḏon, and offered the Pesaḥ on the fourteenth day of the first month; having appointed the kohenim according to their
daily services, being dressed in long garments, in the Hĕyḵal of HWHY.
of Yisra’ĕl, that they should qadosh themselves to
your shoulders; now therefore serve HWHY your Elohim, and serve His people Yisra’ĕl, and prepare yourselves according to your families and clans, according to the order of Dawiḏ the sovereign of

Yisra’ĕl, and according to the splendour of his son Shelomoh. And stand in the Hĕyḵal according to the heads of the families of the Lĕwites, who serve in the presence of your brothers the children of Yisra’ĕl. Slaughter the Pesaḥ in order, and prepare the
offerings for your brothers, and guard the Pesaḥ according to the Command of HWHY, which was given to Mosheh.” And to the people who were found there,

Yoshiyahu gave thirty thousand lambs and young goats, and three thousand calves; these were given to the people from the sovereign’s allowance, according to his promise, to the kohenim, and to the Lĕwites. And Ḥilqiyahu, Zeḵaryah, and Yeḥi’ĕl, the
governors of the Hĕyḵal, gave to the kohenim two thousand six hundred sheep, and three hundred calves for the Pesaḥ. And Yeḵonyah and Shemayah and Nethan’ĕl his
brother and Ḥashaḇyah, and Aḥi’ĕl and Yoram, captains over thousands, gave to the Lĕwites five 1320
Lĕwites, having the unleavened bread, stood in proper order according to their clans, and according to the nobility of the fathers before
the people, to offer to HWHY, as it is written in the Book of Mosheh. And thus they did in the morning, and they roasted the Pesaḥ with fire, as required.
As for the slaughterings, they boiled them in bronze pots and cauldrons with a pleasing flavour, and put them before all the people; and afterward
they prepared for themselves, and for the kohenim their brothers, the sons of Aharon. For the kohenim offered the fat until evening, and
the Lĕwites prepared for themselves, and their brothers the kohenim, the sons of Aharon.
in their service, according to the appointment of Dawiḏ, that is: Asaph, Zeḵaryah, and Yeḏuthun, who were of the sovereign’s servants. And the gatekeepers were at every gate - it was not
lawful for any to go from his regular service - for their brothers the Lĕwites prepared for them. Thus the matters which pertained to the
slaughterings of HWHY were accomplished on that day, that they might hold the Pesaḥ, and offer slaughterings upon the altar of HWHY,
according to the command of sovereign Yoshiyahu. So the children of Yisra’ĕl who were present held
the Pesaḥ at that time, and the Feast of Matstsoth seven days; and such a Pesaḥ was not kept in Yisra’ĕl since the
time of the naḇi Shemu’ĕl. Even all the sovereigns of Yisra’ĕl did not keep
such a Pesaḥ as Yoshiyahu, and the kohenim and the Lĕwites and the Yahuḏim held with all Yisra’ĕl who were found dwelling at Yerushalayim. 1321
Pesaḥ was kept. And the works of Yoshiyahu were upright before his
Aḏon with a reverent heart. As for that which came to be in his time, they were

written in former times, concerning those who sinned, and acted wickedly against HWHY above all people and reigns, and how they grieved Him exceedingly, so that the words of HWHY rose up against Yisra’ĕl.
that Pharaoh the sovereign of Mitsrayim came to battle at Karkemish on the Perath; and Yoshiyahu went out against him. But the sovereign of Mitsrayim sent to him, saying,
“What have I to do with you, O sovereign of Yahuḏah? I am not sent out against you by HWHY Elohim; for
my battle is at Perath. And now indeed, HWHY is with me. HWHY is with me urging me forward. Depart from me, and do not be against HWHY.” However Yoshiyahu did not turn back his chariot
from him, but undertook to fight with him, not regarding the words of the naḇi Yirmeyahu spoken by the mouth of HWHY; but joined in battle against him in the plain of
Meḡiddo, and the princes came against sovereign Yoshiyahu. Then the sovereign said to his servants, “Carry me
away out of the battle; for I am very weak.” And immediately his servants took him away out of the battle. Then mounting his second chariot, and being
brought back to Yerushalayim, he died and was buried in his father’s tomb; and all the Yahuḏim mourned for Yoshiyahu. Also

Yirmeyahu the naḇi lamented for Yoshiyahu, and the chief men with the women made lamentation for him to this day. And this was ordained for a law to be done continually in all the nation of Yisra’ĕl. 1322
Yoshiyahu, and made him sovereign instead of Yoshiyahu his father, when he was twenty-three years old. And he reigned in Yahuḏah and in Yerushalayim
three months; and then the sovereign of Mitsrayim removed him from the reign in Yerushalayim. And he placed a tax over the land of a hundred
kiḵars of silver and one kiḵar of gold. The sovereign of Mitsrayim also made sovereign
Yahoyaqim his brother sovereign of Yahuḏah and Yerushalayim. And Yahoyaqim imprisoned the nobles, but he
seized Tseruyah his brother, and brought him out of Mitsrayim. Yahoyaqim was twenty-five years old when he was
made sovereign in the land of Yahuḏah and Yerushalayim; and he did evil before HWHY. Therefore Neḇuḵaḏnetstsar the sovereign of Baḇel
came up against him, and bound him with chains of bronze, and carried him away to Baḇel.
HWHY, and carried them away, and put them in his own temple at Baḇel. And those matters that are written concerning him,
and of his uncleanness and unrighteousness, are written in the annals of the sovereigns. And Yoyaqim his son reigned in his place; he was
made sovereign being eighteen years old; and he reigned only three months and ten days in
Yerushalayim; and did evil before HWHY. 1323
Yerushalayim, when he was twenty-one years old; and he reigned eleven years. And he also did evil in the eyes of HWHY, and took
no heed of the words that were spoken to him by the naḇi Yirmeyahu from the mouth of HWHY. And after sovereign Neḇuḵaḏnetstsar had made

him swear by the Name of HWHY, he broke his oath, and rebelled; and hardening his neck and his heart, he transgressed the Laws of HWHY Elohim of Yisra’ĕl. The governors of the people and of the kohenim

also did much against the Laws, and surpassed all the abominations of the other nations, and defiled the Hĕyḵal of HWHY, which was qadosh in Yerushalayim. Nevertheless the Elohim of their fathers sent His
messenger to call them back, because He spared them and also His Mishkan. But they mocked His messengers; and see, when
HWHY spoke to them, they mocked His neḇi’im so much that He, being wroth with His people for
their great unrighteousness, commanded the sovereigns of the Kasdites to come up against them; who slew their young men with the sword, even
small and great, with the vessels of the ark of Elohim, and the sovereign’s treasures, and carried them away to Baḇel. As for the House of HWHY, they burned it, and broke
down the walls of Yerushalayim, and lit her towers on fire. And as for her esteemed objects, they never
ceased till they had consumed and brought them all to 1324
the Parasians reigned, to fill the Word of HWHY spoken by the mouth of Yirmeyahu: “Until the land had enjoyed her Shabbathoth. As
long as she lay waste she kept Shabbath, until seventy years were completed.”
In the first year of Koresh sovereign of Paras, in order to accomplish the Word of HWHY by the mouth of Yirmeyahu, HWHY stirred up the spirit of Koresh sovereign of
Paras, so that he called out in all his reign, and also put it in writing, saying, “Thus said Koresh sovereign of Paras;
HWHY of Yisra’ĕl, the Most High Ĕl, has made me sovereign of the whole world, and commanded me to build Him a House at
Yerushalayim in Yahuḏah. “If therefore there are any of you who are of His

people, let HWHY, even his Aḏon, be with him, and let him go up to Yerushalayim that is in Yahuḏah, and build the House of HWHY of Yisra’ĕl, for He is HWHY who dwells in Yerushalayim. “Whoever then dwells in the places round about, I
say, let them help him - those who are his neighbours - with gold and with silver, with gifts, with horses and with cattle, and other
goods which have been presented with a vow, for the Hĕyḵal of HWHY at Yerushalayim.” Then the chiefs of the families of Yahuḏah and of

the tribe of Binyamin stood up; the kohenim also, and the Lĕwites and all those whose heart HWHY had moved to go up and to build a House for HWHY at Yerushalayim. And those who dwelt round about them helped
them in all matters with silver and gold, with horses and cattle, and with very many gifts of a great number whose hearts were stirred up to do so. 1325
vessels, which Neḇuḵaḏnetstsar had carried away from Yerushalayim, and had put up in his temple of idols. Now when Koresh sovereign of Paras had brought
them out, he delivered them to Mithreḏath his treasurer; And by him they were delivered to Shĕshbatstsar
the governor of Yahuḏah. And this was the number of them: one thousand

gold cups, and one thousand of silver, twenty-nine silver fire holders, thirty bowls of gold, and two thousand four hundred and ten of silver, and one thousand other vessels. So all the vessels of gold and of silver which were
carried away, were five thousand four hundred and sixty-nine. These were brought back by Shĕshbatstsar,
together with those in captivity, from Baḇel to Yerushalayim. But in the time of Artaḥshashta sovereign of Paras

Bishlam, and Mithreḏath, and Taḇe’ĕl, and Reḥum the governor, and Shimshai the scribe, with others that were in commission with them dwelling in Shomeron and other places, wrote to him against those who dwelt in Yahuḏah and Yerushalayim these following words: To sovereign Artaḥshashta our master, your
servants - Reḥum the governor, and Shimshai the
the Yahuḏim who came up from you to us, having come to Yerushalayim, that rebellious and wicked city,
shall not only refuse to give tribute, but also rebel against sovereigns. 1326
now in hand, we think it right not to neglect such a matter, but to speak to our master the sovereign, to the
intent that, if it be your pleasure, it may be sought out in the books of your fathers; and you shall find in the annals which are written
concerning these matters, and shall understand that this city was rebellious, troubling both sovereigns and cities; and that the Yahuḏim were rebellious, and raised
continuous wars; which is the very reason this city was made desolate. Therefore we do now declare unto you, O master
the sovereign, that if this city be built again, and its walls rebuilt, you shall no longer have passage into Koĕlĕ-Suria and Phoinikĕ. Then the sovereign wrote back again to Reḥum the
governor, to Shimshai the scribe, and to the rest of their companions, and dwellers in Shomeron and Suria and Phoinikĕ, after this manner: I have read the letter which you have sent to me;
therefore I commanded to make diligent search, and it has been found that this city was from the beginning exercising against sovereigns; And the men within were given to rebellion and
fighting, and that mighty and harsh sovereigns were in Yerushalayim, who reigned and exacted tributes in Koĕlĕ-Suria and Phoinikĕ. Now therefore I have commanded to prevent those
men from building the city, and take heed that there be no more done in it; and that those wicked workers proceed no further
to the annoyance of sovereigns. Then when the letter from sovereign Artaḥshashta

had been read, Reḥum and Shimshai the scribe and the rest of their companions hurried to Yerushalayim with a troop of horsemen, and a crowd of people in battle array began to hinder the builders; and the 1327
Now when Dareyawesh reigned, he made a great feast for all his subjects and for all his household and for all the princes of Maḏai and Paras, and for all the governors and captains and viceroys
that were under him, from Hodu to Kush, in a hundred and twenty-seven provinces. And when they had eaten and drank, and being
satisfied had gone home, then Dareyawesh the sovereign went into his bedroom and slept, and soon after awoke. Then three young men who were of the guards that
guarded the sovereign personally spoke one to another, “Let each one of us speak a word of that which is

strongest, and whose words shall seem wiser than the others, to him shall the sovereign Dareyawesh give great gifts, and great esteem in overcoming; to be clothed in purple, to drink from gold, and to
sleep on gold, and a chariot with bridles of gold, and a turban of fine linen, and a chain about his neck. “And he shall sit next to Dareyawesh because of
his wisdom, and shall be called a relative of Dareyawesh.” And then every one wrote his words, sealed it, and
laid it under the pillow of sovereign Dareyawesh; and said, “When the sovereign has risen, someone

shall give him the writings; and of whose side the sovereign and the three princes of Paras shall judge his words to be the wisest, he shall have overcome, as was agreed.” The first wrote: Wine is the strongest.
The second wrote: The sovereign is strongest.
The third wrote: Women are strongest; but above
writings, and delivered them to him, and so he read them. And having sent, he called all the princes of Paras
and Maḏai, and the governors, and the captains, and the viceroys, and the chief officers; and he sat down on the royal seat of judgment; and
the writings were read before them. And he said, “Call the young men, and they shall
declare their own words.” So they were called, and came in. And he said to them, “Speak to us your thoughts
concerning the writings.” Then the first, who had spoken of the strength of wine, began, and he said, “O you men, how exceedingly strong
is wine! It causes all men who drink it to stray. “It makes the mind of the sovereign and of the
fatherless child to all be equal; of the slave and the free, of the poor and the wealthy. “It also turns every thought into joy and rejoicing, so
that a man remembers neither sorrow nor debt, and it brings wealth to every heart, so that a man
remembers neither sovereign nor governor; and it causes to speak of all in coins. “And when they are in their cups, they forget their
love to both friends and brothers, and a little after draw out swords. “But when they are from the wine, they do not
remember what they have done. “O you men, is not wine, that forces to do this, the
strongest?” And when he had so spoken, he remained silent.
Then the second, that had spoken of the strength of the sovereign, began to speak: “O you men, do not men who reign over sea and
land and all in them excel in strength? “And yet the sovereign is mightier; for he is master
of all these, and rules over them, and whatever he commands them they do. 1329
other, they do it; if he sends them out against their enemies, they go, and tear down mountains, walls and towers. “They slay and are slain, but do not disobey the
sovereign’s command. If they overcome, they bring all to the sovereign, as well the spoil, and all other matters. “Likewise for those who are not soldiers, and have

naught to do with wars, but are farmers; when they have reaped again that which they had sown, they bring it to the sovereign, and compel one another to pay tribute to the sovereign. “And yet he is but one man. If he commands to kill,
they kill; if he commands to spare, they spare; “If he commands to smite, they smite; if he
commands to destroy, they destroy; if he commands to build, they build; if he commands to cut down, they cut down; if he
commands to plant, they plant. “So all his people and his armies obey him;
furthermore he lies down, he eats and drinks, and takes his rest, and these keep watch around about him, neither
may anyone depart, and do his own business, nor do they disobey him in any matter. “O you men, how should not the sovereign be
mightiest, when he is obeyed in such a way?” And he kept silent. Then the third, who had spoken of women, and of
crowd of men, neither is it wine that excels. Who is it then that rules them, or has the rulership over them? Are they not women? “Women have borne the sovereign and all the
people that reign by sea and land. 1330
nourished those who planted the vineyards, from where the wine comes. “These also make garments for men; these bring
esteem to men, and without women, men cannot be. “Indeed, and if men have gathered together gold
and silver, or any other luxury, do they not love a woman who is lovely in appearance and loveliness? “And letting all those go, do they not gape, and
even with open mouth fix their eyes fast on her; and do not all men have more desire for her than for silver or gold, or any luxury whatever? “A man leaves his own father who raised him, and
his own land, and clings to his wife. “He does not remain, and remembers neither
father, nor mother, nor land, to spend his life with his wife. “By this you also must know that women have rule
over you. Do you not labour and toil, and bring and give all to the woman? “Indeed, a man takes his sword, and goes his way
to rob and to steal, to sail over the sea and upon rivers, and faces a lion, and goes in the darkness; and
when he has stolen, plundered, and robbed, he brings it to his love. “Therefore a man loves his wife better than father
or mother. “Indeed, there are many that have lost their minds
for women, and become servants for their sakes. “Many also have perished, have strayed, and
sinned, for women. “And now do you not believe me? Is not the
sovereign great in his power? Do not all countries fear to touch him? “Yet I saw him and Apamĕ the sovereign’s
concubine, the daughter of the admirable Bartakos, sitting at the right hand of the sovereign, 1331
and putting it upon her own head; she also struck the sovereign with her left hand. “And yet for all this the sovereign gaped and gazed

upon her with open mouth. If she laughed at him, he laughed also; but if she took any displeasure in him, the sovereign was eager to flatter, that she might be reconciled to him again. “O you men, how could it be but women are
strongest, seeing they do this?” Then the sovereign and the princes looked at each

earth, high is the shamayim, swift is the sun in its course, for it makes the circuit of the shamayim, and follows its course again to its own place in one day. “Is He who makes these not great? Therefore the
shamayim baraḵ it. All works shake and tremble at it, and there is no unrighteousness with it. “Wine is wicked, the sovereign is wicked, women
are wicked, all the children of men are wicked, and
lives and overcomes forever. “With her there is no partiality or preference; but
she does that which is righteous, and refrains from all unrighteousness and wickedness; and all men approve of her works. “Nor is there any unrighteousness in her judgment;
but she is the strength, reign, power, and excellence,

would, more than what is appointed in the writing, and we shall give it to you, because you have been found wisest; and you shall sit next to me, and shall be called my relative.” Then he said to the sovereign, “Remember your
vow to build Yerushalayim, which you swore in the day when you came to your reign, and to send all the vessels that were taken away
from Yerushalayim, which Koresh put aside, when he vowed to destroy Baḇel, and to send them there again. “You have also vowed to rebuild the Hĕyḵal, which
the Eḏomites burned when Yahuḏah was laid waste by the Kasdites. “And now, O master the sovereign, this is that

which I require, and which I desire from you, and this is the princely kindness proceeding from yourself: I desire therefore that you fulfill the vow, the works of which you have vowed with your own mouth to the Sovereign of the shamayim.” Then Dareyawesh the sovereign stood up, and

kissed him, and wrote letters for him to all the treasurers and viceroys and captains and governors, that they should safely transfer both he, and all those who would go up with him to rebuild Yerushalayim. He also wrote letters to the viceroys that were in

Koĕlĕ-Suria and Phoinikĕ, and to those in Leḇanon, that they should bring cedar wood from Leḇanon to Yerushalayim, and that they should build the city with him. And he wrote for all the Yahuḏim that went out of
his reign up into Yahuḏah, concerning their freedom, that no officer, no ruler, no viceroy, nor treasurer, should forcibly enter into their doors; and that all the land which they hold should be free
without tribute; and that the Eḏomites should give up the villages of the Yahuḏim which they held; 1333
yearly toward the building of the Hĕyḵal, until the time that it was built; and another ten kiḵars yearly, to maintain the burnt
offerings on the altar every day, for they had a Command to offer seventeen; and that all those who went from Baḇel to build the
city should have freedom, they as well as their descendants, and all the kohenim that went away. He also wrote concerning their support, and the
garments of the kohenim in which they serve; and also for the support of the Lĕwites to be given
to them until the day that the House was finished, and Yerushalayim built up. And he commanded to give land and wages to all
who guarded the city. He also sent away all the vessels from Baḇel that
Koresh had put aside; and all that Koresh had commanded to be given, he also commanded the same to be done, and sent to Yerushalayim. Now when the young man went out, he lifted up his
face to the shamayim toward Yerushalayim, and praised the Sovereign of the shamayim, and said, “From You comes deliverance, from You
comes wisdom, and Yours is the esteem, and I am Your servant. “Baruḵ are You, who has given me wisdom; for I
give thanks to You, O HWHY of our fathers.” And so he took the letters, and went out, and came
to Baḇel, and told all his brothers, and they praised the Elohim of their fathers,
because He had given them release and freedom to go up, and to build Yerushalayim, and the Hĕyḵal
which is called by His Name. And they feasted with musical instruments and gladness seven days.
After this the heads of the families were chosen according to their tribes, to go up with their wives and sons and daughters, with their male servants and female servants, and their cattle. 1334

Command in the Book of Mosheh, the man of Elohim. And some from the other nations of the land were

gathered to them. And they put up the altar in its place, because all the nations of the land were at enmity with them, and oppressed them; and they brought offerings at the appointed times, and burnt offerings to HWHY both morning and evening. They also held the Feast of Sukkoth, as it is
commanded in the Torah, and brought offerings daily, as appointed. And after that, the continual offerings, and the
offering of the Shabbathoth, and of the new moons,
began to offer offerings to Elohim from the first day of the seventh month, although the Hĕyḵal of HWHY had not yet been built. And they gave silver, food and drink to the masons
and carpenters with gladness. To those of Tsiḏon and Tsor they also gave by

weight, that they should bring cedars from Leḇanon, which would be brought by boat to the harbour of Yapho, according to the command given them by Koresh sovereign of Paras. And in the second year and second month after

their coming to the Hĕyḵal of Elohim at Yerushalayim, Zerubbaḇel the son of She’alti’ĕl, and Yĕshua the son of Yotsaḏaq, and their brothers, and the kohenim, and the Lĕwites began, and all those who had come to Yerushalayim out of the captivity; and they laid the foundation of the House of Elohim
on the first day of the second month, in the second 1339

old over the works of HWHY. Then Yĕshua stood up, and his sons and brothers, and Qaḏmi’ĕl his brother, and the sons of Mĕyḏeḇa, with the sons of Yaḏa the son of Elyaḏa, with their sons and brothers; all Lĕwites, with one accord pressed forward with the work, labouring to advance the work on the House of Elohim. So the workmen built the Hĕyḵal of HWHY. And the kohenim stood dressed in their garments
with musical instruments and trumpets; and the Lĕwites, the sons of Asaph had cymbals, singing songs of thanksgiving, and praising HWHY,
as directed by Dawiḏ the sovereign of Yisra’ĕl. And they sang songs to the praise of HWHY with
loud voices, because His kindness and esteem in all Yisra’ĕl is forever. And all the people sounded trumpets, and shouted
with a loud voice, singing songs of thanksgiving to HWHY for the raising of the House of HWHY. Also of the kohenim and Lĕwites, and of the chief
of their families, the elders who had seen the former House came to the building with crying and great weeping. And many with trumpets and joy shouted with a
loud voice, so that the trumpets could not be heard for the
weeping of the people; yet the crowd sounded greatly, so that it was heard from afar. Therefore when the enemies of the tribe of
Yahuḏah and Binyamin heard it, they came to know what the noise of trumpets meant. And they perceived that those who were from the
captivity had built the Hĕyḵal to HWHY Elohim of Yisra’ĕl. So they went to Zerubbaḇel and Yĕshua, and to the
heads of the families, and said to them, “We shall build together with you, 1340
slaughtered to Him from the days of Ĕsarḥaddon the sovereign of Ashshur, who brought us here.” Then Zerubbaḇel and Yĕshua and the heads of the
families of Yisra’ĕl said to them, “It is not for you and us to build a House to HWHY our Elohim together. “We ourselves alone shall build to HWHY of Yisra’ĕl,
according to the command given us by Koresh the sovereign of Paras.” But the foreigners of the land relying heavily on the
inhabitants of Yahuḏah, and restricting their supplies, hindered their building; and by their secret schemes, and popular

persuasions and unrest, they hindered the completion of the building the whole time that sovereign Koresh lived; so they were hindered from building for the space of two years, until the reign of Dareyawesh.

Now in the second year of the reign of Dareyawesh Ḥaggai and Zeḵaryah the son of Iddo, the neḇi’im, naḇa to the Yahuḏim in Yahuḏah and Yerushalayim in the Name of HWHY Elohim of Yisra’ĕl, which was upon them. Then Zerubbaḇel the son of She’alti’ĕl stood up,
and Yĕshua the son of Yotsaḏaq, and began to build the House of HWHY at Yerushalayim, assisted by the neḇi’im of HWHY who were with them. At the same time Tattenai the governor of Suria
came to them and Phoinikĕ, with Shethar-Bozenai and his companions, and said to them, “By whose decree do you build this House and this
roof, and doing all these other matters? And who are the workmen that perform these?” Nevertheless the elders of the Yahuḏim obtained
favour, because HWHY had overseen the captivity; and they were not hindered from building, until such
time as word was given to Dareyawesh concerning them, and an answer received. The copy of the letters which Tattenai, governor of
Suria and Phoinikĕ, and Shethar-Bozenai, with their 1341

sovereign, that having come into the land of Yahuḏah, and entered into the city of Yerushalayim we found in the city of Yerushalayim the elders of the Yahuḏim who were of the captivity building a great and new House to HWHY, of hewn
and costly stones, and the timber already laid upon the walls. And those works are done with great speed, and
the work is prospering in their hands, and being done with all esteem and diligence. Then we asked these elders, saying, “By whose
command are you building this House, and laying the foundations of these works?” Therefore with the purpose that we might make
known to you in writing, we demanded of those who were the chief workers, and we required from them the names of their heads in writing. So they gave us this answer, “We are the servants
of HWHY who made the shamayim and earth. “And as for this House, it was built many years ago
by a great and strong sovereign of Yisra’ĕl, and was finished. “But when our fathers provoked Elohim to wrath,
and sinned against HWHY of Yisra’ĕl who is in the shamayim, He gave them over to the power of Neḇuḵaḏnetstsar sovereign of Baḇel, of the Kasdites; who pulled down the House, and burned it, and
carried away the people captive to Baḇel. “But in the first year that sovereign Koresh reigned
over the land of Baḇel, Koresh the sovereign wrote to build up this House.
Neḇuḵaḏnetstsar had carried away out of the House at Yerushalayim, and had put them in his own temple; these Koresh the sovereign brought out again from the 1342
vessels, and put them in the Hĕyḵal at Yerushalayim; and that the Hĕyḵal of HWHY should be built in its place. “Then the same Shĕshbatstsar, having come here,
laid the foundations of the House of HWHY at Yerushalayim; and from that time to this, is still under construction; it is not yet fully complete. “Now therefore, if it seems good to the sovereign,
let a search be made among the records of sovereign Koresh; and if it is found that the building of the House of
HWHY at Yerushalayim has been done with the consent of sovereign Koresh, and if our master the sovereign approves, let him inform us of this.” Then sovereign Dareyawesh commanded to

search among the records at Baḇel; and so at Aḥmetha the palace, which is in the land of Maḏai, there was found a scroll in which these matters were recorded. In the first year of the reign of Koresh, sovereign
Koresh ordered that the House of HWHY at Yerushalayim should be built again, where they offer with continual fire; the height of which shall be sixty ammah and the
width sixty ammah, with three rows of hewn stones, and one row of new wood from the land; and the expenses of it to be given out of the house of sovereign Koresh;

both of gold and silver, that Neḇuḵaḏnetstsar took out of the House at Yerushalayim, and brought to Baḇel, should be restored to the House at Yerushalayim, and be put in the place where they were before. And he also commanded that Tattenai the governor
of Suria and Phoinikĕ, and Shethar-Bozenai, and their companions, and those who were appointed rulers in Suria and Phoinikĕ, should bear in mind not to strive 1343
again; and that they look diligently to help those who are of the captivity of the Yahuḏim, till the House of HWHY is finished; and out of the tribute of Koĕlĕ-Suria and Phoinikĕ a
portion diligently to be given to these men for the slaughterings of HWHY, that is, to Zerubbaḇel the governor; for bulls and rams and lambs; and also corn, salt, wine and oil, and continually
every year without further question, what is required by the kohenim who are in Yerushalayim to be used daily; that offerings may be made to the Most High Elohim
for the sovereign and for his children, and that they may pray for their lives. And he commanded that whoever would

transgress, or even diminish any word spoken or written before, a timber should be taken out of his own house, and he be hanged upon it, and all his goods seized for the sovereign. Therefore may HWHY, whose Name is called upon
there, utterly destroy every sovereign and nation, that stretches out his hand to hinder or damage the House of HWHY in Yerushalayim. I, Dareyawesh the sovereign have ordained that it
be done according to these words with diligence.
Then following the commands of sovereign Dareyawesh, Tattenai the governor of Koĕlĕ-Suria and Phoinikĕ, and Shethar-Bozenai, with their companions,
elders of the Yahuḏim and governors of the Hĕyḵal.

and Lĕwites, have not put away the foreigners of the land from them, nor the defilements of the gentiles that is, of the Kena’anites, Ḥittites, Perizzites, Yeḇusites, and the Mo’aḇites, Mitsrites, and Eḏomites. For both they and their sons have married with their
HWHY Elohim of Yisra’ĕl assembled to me, while I 1351
before Your face; for our sins have multiplied above our heads, and
our ignorances have reached up to the shamayim. “For ever since the time of our fathers we have

shown to us from You, O HWHY, that there should be left to us a root and a name in the place of Your Miqdash; and to uncover for us a light in the House of HWHY
our Elohim, and to give us food in the time of our service. “Indeed, when we were in bondage, we were not
forsaken by our Aḏon; but He made us favourable before the sovereigns of Paras, so that they gave us food; and also esteemed the Hĕyḵal of our Aḏon, and

these? For we have transgressed Your Commands, which You gave by the hand of Your servants the neḇi’im, saying, ‘The land, which you enter in to possess as an
inheritance, is a land defiled with the abominations of the gentiles of the land, and they have filled it with their uncleanness. 1352
unto their sons, neither shall you take their daughters for your sons. ‘And you shall never seek to have peace with them,

because of our wicked works and great sins! And You, O HWHY, lifted our sins, and gave to us a root, but we have turned back
again to transgress Your Torah, and to mingle ourselves with the uncleanness of the nations of the land. “Were You not wroth with us to destroy us, till You
had left us neither root, seed nor name? “O HWHY of Yisra’ĕl, You are true! For we are left a
root this day. “See, we are now before You in our wickednesses,
for we cannot stand any longer by reason of these matters before You.”

Amaryah, son of Azaryah, son of Merĕmoth, son of Arna, son of Uzzi, son of Buqqi, son of Aḇishua, Pineḥas, son of Eli’ezer, son of Aharon, of the tribe of Lĕwi; who was captive

“Go your way, and show My people their sinful
deeds, and their children their wickedness which they have done against Me; that they may tell their children’s children. “Because the sins of their fathers are increased in
them; for they have forgotten Me, and have offered to foreign mighty ones. “Am not I even He who brought them out of the land
of Mitsrayim, from the house of bondage? But they have provoked Me to wrath, and despised My counsels. “Pull off the hair from your head, and throw all evil
upon them, for they have not been obedient to My Law, but are a rebellious people. “How long shall I endure them, to whom I have
done so much good? “I have destroyed many sovereigns for their sakes;
I have struck down Pharaoh with his servants and all his strength. “I have destroyed all the nations before them, and
in the east I have scattered the people of two provinces, even of Tsor and Tsiḏon, and have slain all their enemies. “Therefore you speak to them, saying, ‘Thus says
hWhY, 1358
gave you a wide and safe passage. I gave you Mosheh for a leader, and Aharon for a kohĕn. “I gave you light in a pillar of fire, and I have done
great wonders among you; yet have you forgotten Me,” says hWhY. ‘Thus says hWhY the Almighty, “The quails were as
a sign to you; I gave you booths for your safety; still you grumbled there, and did not overcome in My Name for the
destruction of your enemies, but even to this day you still grumble. “Where is the good that I have done for you? When
you were hungry and thirsty in the wilderness, did you not cry out to Me, saying, ‘Why have You brought us into this
wilderness to kill us? It would have been better for us to have served the Mitsrites, than to die in this wilderness!’ “Then I took pity on your groaning, and gave you
manna to eat; so you ate bread of messengers. “When you were thirsty, did I not split the rock, and
waters flowed out to your fill? For the heat I covered you with the leaves of the trees. “I divided among you a fruitful land, I drove out the
Kena’anites, the Perizzites and the Pelishtites before you. What more shall I do for you?” says hWhY. ‘Thus says hWhY the Almighty, “When you were in
the wilderness, at the river of the Amorites, thirsting, and blaspheming My Name, I did not send fire for your blasphemies, but threw
a branch in the water, and made the river sweet. “What shall I do unto you, O Ya’aqoḇ? You,
Yahuḏah, would not obey me. I shall turn myself to other nations, and to them I shall give My Name, that they may guard My Laws. “Seeing you have forsaken Me, I shall also forsake
you. When you desire for Me to show favour to you, I shall show no kindness to you. 1359
you have defiled your hands with blood, and your feet are swift to commit murder. “It is not as though you have forsaken Me, but your
own selves,” says hWhY. ‘Thus says hWhY the Almighty, “Have I not treated
you as a father his sons, as a mother her daughters, and a nurse her young infants, that you would be my people, and I should be your
Elohim; that you would be my children, and I should be your Father? “I gathered you together, as a hen gathers her
chickens under her wings; but now, what shall I do to you? I shall throw you out from My presence. “When you offer unto Me, I shall turn my face from
you; for I have rejected your Moedim, your new moons, and your circumcisions. “I sent to you My servants the neḇi’im, whom you
have taken and slain, and torn their bodies in pieces, whose blood I shall require of your hands,” says hWhY. ‘Thus says the Almighty, “Your house is laid waste,
I shall cast you out as the wind does stubble. “And your children shall not be fruitful; for they have
despised My Command, and done that which is evil before Me. “I shall give your houses to a people that shall
come; who having not yet heard of Me, shall believe Me; to whom I have showed no signs, yet they shall do what I have Commanded them. “They have seen no neḇi’im, yet they call their sins
to remembrance, and acknowledge them. “I call to witness the favour of the people to come,
whose little ones rejoice in gladness, and though they have not seen Me with bodily eyes, yet in spirit they believe the Word that I say. “And now brother, see what esteem; and see the
people that come from the East, 1360
Zeḵaryah and Mal’aḵi, who is also called a messenger of HWHY.” ’

‘Thus says hWhY, “I brought this people out of bondage, and I gave them My Commands by My servants the neḇi’im; whom they would not hear, but despised My counsels. “The mother that bore them says to them, ‘Go your
way, you children; for I am a widow and forsaken. ‘I brought you up with gladness; but with sorrow and

forsaken; go your way, O My children, and ask kindness from hWhY.’ “As for Me, O father, I call upon you for a witness

let their names be blotted out from the earth; for they have despised My Covenant. “Woe to you, Ashshur, you that hide the
unrighteous within you! O you wicked people, remember what I did to Seḏom and Amorah; whose land lies in lumps of tar and piles of ashes;
even so I shall do the same to those who do not listen to Me.” says hWhY the Almighty.’ ”
