Pelishtites, and when he had pulled down their altars and burned their carved images with fire and plundered their cities, he returned to the land of Yahuḏah.

About that time sovereign Antioḵos travelling through the high countries heard it said that Elumais in the country of Paras was a city greatly renowned for riches, silver and gold; and that there was a very rich temple in it in which

were coverings of gold and breastplates and shields which Alexandros, son of Philippos the Makedonian sovereign, who reigned first among the Yawanites, had left there. Therefore he came and sought to take the city, and
to plunder it; but he was not able, because those of the city having had warning, rose up against him in battle. So he fled and
departed from there in great distress, and returned to Baḇel. And there came one who brought him news of
Paras, that the armies, which went against the land of Yahuḏah, were put to flight, 1454

strength was driven away by the Yahuḏim; and that they were strengthened by the armour and strength and store of plunder, which they had taken from the armies whom they had destroyed. Also, that they had pulled down the abomination,
which he had placed upon the altar in Yerushalayim, and that they had surrounded the Miqdash with high walls as before, and its city Bĕyth Tsur. Now when the sovereign heard these words, he
was astonished and distressed, so he laid himself down on his bed, and fell sick for grief, because it had not resulted as he planned. And there he stayed many days, for his grief
increased further, and he thought that he would die. So he called for all his friends, and said to them,
“The sleep is gone from my eyes, and my heart fails for every concern. “And I thought within myself, ‘Into what tribulation
have I come, and how great a flood of misery it is, in which I now am!’ for I was respectable and well loved in my power. “But now I remember the evils that I did at
Yerushalayim, and that I took all the vessels of gold and silver that were there, and sent to destroy the inhabitants of Yahuḏah without reason. “I perceive therefore, that for this reason these
troubles have come upon me, and, see, I perish through great grief in a strange land.” Then he called for Philippos, one of his friends, who
he made ruler over all his reign, and gave him the crown, and his robe, and his seal,
so that he should bring up his son Antioḵos, and raise him up for the reign. So sovereign Antioḵos died there in the hundred
and forty-ninth year. 1455
dead, he appointed Antioḵos his son, whom he had brought up from youth to reign in his place, and his name he called Eupator. About this time those that were in the fortress
enclosed the Yisra’ĕlites round about the Miqdash, and continually sought their evil, and the strengthening of the gentiles. Therefore Yahuḏah, intending to destroy them,
called all the people together to besiege them. So they came together, and besieged them in the
hundred and fiftieth year, and he made mounts for shot against them, and other engines. However some of those that were besieged
escaped, to whom some wicked men of Yisra’ĕl joined themselves. And they went to the sovereign, and said, “How
long will it be till you execute judgment, and avenge our brothers? “We have been willing to serve your father, and do
as he would have us, and to obey his commands. “For this reason those of our nation besiege the
fortress, and are alienated from us! And as many of us as they could fall upon, they slew, and plundered our inheritance. “Neither have they stretched out their hand against
us alone, but also against their borders. “And, see, this day they are besieging the fortress
at Yerushalayim, to take it; the Miqdash also, and they have fortified Bĕyth Tsur. “Therefore if you do not prevent them quickly, they
will do greater matters than these, neither shall you be able to rule them.” Now when the sovereign heard this, he was wroth,
and gathered together all his associates and the captains of his army, and those that had charge of the horses. 1456
from other reigns, and from islands of the sea, so that the number of his army was a hundred
thousand footmen, and twenty thousand horsemen, and thirty-two elephants trained for battle. These went through Eḏom, and encamped against
Bĕyth Tsur, which they assaulted many days, making engines of battle. But those of Bĕyth Tsur came out, and burned them with fire, and fought bravely. After this, Yahuḏah moved from the fortress, and
encamped in Bĕyth Zeḵaryah, opposite the sovereign’s camp. Then the sovereign rising very early, marched
fiercely with his army toward Bĕyth Zeḵaryah, where his armies prepared for battle, and sounded the trumpets. And so, that they might provoke the elephants to
fight, they showed them the blood of grapes and mulberries. And they divided the beasts among the armies, and

for every elephant they appointed one thousand men, armed with coats of mail, and with bronze helmets on their heads. And besides this, for every beast were assigned five hundred of the best horsemen. These were ready at every occasion. Wherever the
beast was, and wherever the beast went, they went also, neither did they depart from it. And upon the beasts there were strong wooden

towers, which covered every one of them, and were girded tightly to them with devices. There were also, thirty-two strong men on every one that fought upon them, besides the Hodite that directed it. As for the remainder of the horsemen, they
positioned them on this side and that side of the two divisions of the army giving them signals what to do, and being armed all over among the ranks. 1457
and bronze, the mountains glistened, and shone like lamps of fire. So part of the sovereign’s army being spread over
the high mountains, and part on the valleys below, marched on boldly and in formation. Therefore all that heard the noise of their multitude,
and the marching of the army, and the rattling of the armour, were moved; for the army was very great and mighty. Then Yahuḏah and his army drew near, and joined
in battle, and six hundred men of the sovereign’s army were slain. Eli’ezer, also named Savaran, perceiving that one
of the beasts armed with royal armour, was higher than all the rest, and supposing that the sovereign was upon him, put himself in danger, so that he might deliver his
people, and obtain a lasting name for himself. Therefore he ran upon him courageously through
the midst of the battle, slaying on the right hand and on the left, so that they were divided from him on both sides. Having done so, he crept under the elephant, and
thrust it underneath, and slew it, so the elephant fell down upon him, and he died there. However the rest of the Yahuḏim, seeing the
strength of the sovereign, and the violence of his forces, turned away from them. Then the sovereign’s army went up to
Yerushalayim to meet them, and the sovereign pitched his tents against Yahuḏah, and against Mount Tsiyon. But he made peace with those that were in Bĕyth
Tsur; for they came out of the city, because they had no food there to endure the siege, being a year of rest for the land. 1458
garrison there to guard it. As for the Miqdash, he besieged it many days, and
appointed siege engines there with weapons and instruments to throw fire and stones, and catapults and weapons to shoot arrows. So they also made engines against their engines,
and withheld them in battle a long time. Yet in the end, their containers being without food -
for it was the seventh year, and those in Yahuḏah that were delivered from the gentiles had eaten up the remains of the store. So there were only a few left in the Miqdash, and
because the scarcity of food prevailed against them, they were compelled to disperse themselves, every man to his own place. At that time Lusias heard it said, that Philippos -
whom Antioḵos the sovereign, while he lived - had appointed to bring up his son Antioḵos to be sovereign; had returned from Paras and Maḏai, and the
sovereign’s army that also went with him, and that he planned to seize the control of affairs for himself. Therefore he went in haste, and said to the

sovereign and the captains of the army and the company, “We diminish daily, and our food runs short, and the place we lay siege to is strong, and the affairs of the reign lie upon us. “Now therefore let us be friends with these men,
and make peace with them, and with all their nation; and make a covenant with them, that they shall live
after their Laws, as they did before. For they are displeased because we abolished their Laws, and therefore, have done all these matters.” So the sovereign and the princes were pleased;
therefore he sent to them to make peace, and they accepted. 1459
to them, so they went out of the stronghold. Then the sovereign entered into Mount Tsiyon; but
when he saw the strength of the place, he broke his oath that he had made, and gave command to pull down the wall round about. Afterward he departed in haste, and returned to
Antioḵeia, where he found Philippos to be master of the city. So he fought against him, and took the city by force.

In the one hundred and fiftieth year, Dĕmĕtrios the son of Seleukus departed from Rome, and came up with a few men to a city of the sea coast, and reigned there. And as he entered into the palace of his ancestors,
it had come to pass, that his army had taken Antioḵos and Lusias, to bring them to him. Therefore, when he knew it, he said, “Do not let me
see their faces.” So his army slew them. Now when Dĕmĕtrios was
appointed to the throne of his reign, there came to him all the wicked and evil men of
Yisra’ĕl, having Elyaqim, who desired to be kohĕn ha’gadol, as their captain. And they accused the people before the sovereign,
saying, “Yahuḏah and his brothers have slain all your friends, and driven us out of our own land. “Now therefore, send some man whom you trust,
and let him go and see what disorder he has made among us, and in the sovereign’s land, and let him punish them with all those that assist them.” Then the sovereign chose Bakḵidĕs, a friend of the
sovereign, who ruled beyond the River, and was a great man in the reign, and trustworthy to the sovereign, 1460
made kohĕn ha’gadol, and commanded that he should take vengeance on the children of Yisra’ĕl. So they departed, and came with a large force into
the land of Yahuḏah, where they sent messengers to Yahuḏah and his brothers with peaceable words, deceitfully. But they gave no heed to their words, for they saw
that they had come with a large force. Then a company of scribes gathered to Elyaqim
and Bakḵidĕs, to require right-ruling. Now the Ḥasiḏim were the first among the children
of Yisra’ĕl that sought peace from them, for they said, “One that is a kohĕn of the seed of
Aharon has come with this army, and he will do us no wrong.” So he spoke to them peaceably, and swore to
them, saying, “We will neither do evil to you nor your friends.” So they believed him; however he took from them
sixty men, and slew them in one day, to fill the words which are written:
and their blood they have shed round about Yerushalayim, with no one to bury them.” Therefore the fear and dread of them fell upon all

pitched his tents in Bĕyth Zatha, where he sent and took many of the men that had forsaken him, and some of the people also, and when he had slain them, he threw them into a large pit. Then he entrusted the land to Elyaqim, and left with
him a force to assist him; so Bakḵidĕs returned to the sovereign. 1461
And all those who troubled the people assembled
to him, who, after they had taken the land of Yahuḏah into their power, did much evil in Yisra’ĕl. Now when Yahuḏah saw all the evil that Elyaqim
and his company had done among the Yisra’ĕlites, even more than the gentiles, he went out to all the coastlands of Yahuḏah round
about, and took vengeance on those that had revolted from him, so that they no longer dared go out into the country. On the other side, when Elyaqim saw that Yahuḏah

and his army had gotten the upper hand, and knew that he was not able to withstand their strength, he went again to the sovereign, and said all the worst about them that he could. Then the sovereign sent Nikanor, one of his
honourable princes, a man that bore deadly hatred for Yisra’ĕl, with a command to destroy the people. So Nikanor came to Yerushalayim with a large
force, and sent to Yahuḏah and his brothers deceitfully with friendly words, saying, “Let there be no battle between me and you. I will
come with a few men, that I may see you in peace.” Therefore he came to Yahuḏah, and they greeted
one another peaceably; however the enemies were prepared to take away Yahuḏah with violence. After this matter was known to Yahuḏah, to know
that he came to him with deceit, he was very afraid of him, and would no longer see his face. Also, when Nikanor saw that his plan was
discovered, went out to fight against Yahuḏah beside Kephar Salem, where about five thousand men were slain from
Nikanor’s side, and the rest fled to the city of Dawiḏ. After this went Nikanor up to Mount Tsiyon, and
some of the kohenim and some of the elders of the 1462
abused them shamefully, and spoke proudly, and swore in his wrath, saying, “Unless Yahuḏah
and his army are now delivered into my hands, if I ever come again in safety, I will burn up this House!” and with that he went out in a great rage. Then the kohenim entered in, and stood before the
altar and the Hĕyḵal weeping, and saying, “You, O HWHY, chose this House to be called by
Your Name, and to be a House of prayer and petition for Your people. “Be avenged on this man and his army, and let
them fall by the sword. Remember their blasphemies, and do not allow them to continue any longer.” So Nikanor went out of Yerushalayim, and pitched
his tents in Bĕyth Ḥoron, where an army out of Suria met him. But Yahuḏah pitched in Ḥaḏashah with three
thousand men, and he prayed there saying, “O HWHY, when those that were sent from the
sovereign of Ashshur blasphemed, Your messenger went out, and smote a hundred and eighty-five thousand of them. “In the same way, destroy this army before us
today, that the rest may know that he has spoken blasphemy against Your Miqdash, and judge him according to his wickedness.” So on the thirteenth day of the month Aḏar the
armies joined in battle, but Nikanor’s army was defeated, and he himself was the first slain in the battle. Now when Nikanor’s army saw that he was slain,
they threw down their weapons, and fled. 1463
Ḥaḏashah to Gezer, sounding a shout after them with their trumpets. So they came out from all of the towns of Yahuḏah

round about and closed them in, so that they, turning back upon those that pursued them, were all slain with the sword, and not one of them was left. Afterward they took the spoils, and the plunder, and
smote off Nikanor’s head, and his right hand, which he stretched out so proudly, and took them away, and hanged them up toward Yerushalayim. Because of this the people rejoiced greatly, and
they kept that day as a day of great gladness. And they ordained to guard this day yearly, being
the thirteenth of Aḏar. Thus the land of Yahuḏah was at rest a little while.
was also told of their battles and notable deeds which
in taking the mines of silver and gold which is there; and that by their strategy and patience they had

conquered all that place, though it was very far from them; and of the sovereigns that also came against them from the ends of the earth, till they had defeated them, and given them a great overthrow, so that the rest gave them tribute every year. Besides this, how they had defeated Philippos and
Perseus, sovereign of the Ḥittites in battle, with others that lifted themselves up against them and had overcome them. 1464
came against them in battle, having a hundred and twenty elephants with horsemen and chariots, and a very great army, was defeated by them; and how they took him alive, and made a covenant
that he and those that reigned after him should pay a great tribute and give hostages, and that which was agreed upon. And the country of Hodu, and Maḏai and Ludia and
of the best lands which they took from him and gave to Sovereign Eumĕnĕs. And how the Yawanites had determined to come
and destroy them; and that they, having knowledge of this sent

against them a certain captain, and fighting with them slew many of them, and took away captive their wives and their children, and plundered them, and took possession of their lands, and pulled down their strongholds, and took them to be their servants to this day. It was also told him, how they destroyed and
brought under their rule all other reigns and islands that at any time resisted them, but they kept peace with their friends and those that
relied upon them; and that they had conquered reigns both far and near, so that all that heard of their name were afraid of them. Also that whom they would assist to reign, those
reigned; and again, whom they determined, they displaced. Lastly, that they were greatly exalted, yet for all this, none of them wore a crown or was
clothed in purple, to be made great by it. And, how they had made for themselves a senate
house, in which three hundred and twenty men sat in council daily, consulting always for the people, so that they might be well ordered; 1465
man every year, who ruled over all their country, and that all were obedient to that one, and that there was neither envy nor strife among them. In consideration of these matters, Yahuḏah chose

Eupolemus the son of Yoḥanan, the son of Haqqots, and Yason the son of Eli’ezer, and sent them to Rome, to make a covenant of peace and ally with them, and to ask them that they would take the yoke from
them; for they saw that the reign of the Yawanites oppressed Yisra’ĕl with bondage. So they went to Rome, which was a very great
journey, and came into the senate, where they spoke and said, “Yahuḏah Maqqaḇah with his brothers, and the
people of the Yahuḏim, have sent us to you, to make peace and an alliance with you, and that we might be counted your allies and friends.”
And this is the copy of the letter which the senate
wrote back again on tablets of bronze, and sent to Yerushalayim, that they would possess a memorial of peace and alliance for them there:
people of the Yahuḏim, by sea and by land forever. Also the sword and enemy be far from them. “If there should come first any battle upon the
appointed time with all their heart. “Neither shall they give whatever to those that fight
against them, or aid them with food, weapons, silver,
against them, or weapons, or silver, or ships, as it
covenant with the people of the Yahuḏim. “However, if after this, the one party or the other
shall think by rights to add or diminish whatever, they may do so at their pleasure, and whatever they shall add or take away shall be consented to. “And regarding the evils that Dĕmĕtrios has done
to the Yahuḏim, we have written to him, saying, ‘Why have you made your yoke heavy upon our friends and allies the Yahuḏim? ‘If therefore they complain against you any more,
we will do right by them, and fight with you by sea and by land.’ ”

Furthermore, when Dĕmĕtrios heard that Nikanor and his army were slain in battle, he sent Bakḵidĕs and Elyaqim to the land of Yahuḏah a second time, and with them the main force of his army, who went out by the way that leads to Gilgal, and
pitched their tents before Mĕsaloth, which is in Arbela. And after they had won it, they slew much people. Also, on the first month of the hundred and fifty-
second year, they encamped before Yerushalayim. From there they moved, and went to Beroia, with
twenty thousand footmen and two thousand horsemen. Now Yahuḏah had pitched his tents at El’asah, with
three thousand chosen men with him, who, seeing the multitude of the mighty army
opposing him, was greatly afraid. Therefore many 1467
away, and that the battle pressed upon him, he was greatly troubled in mind and very distressed, for he had no time to assemble them together. Nevertheless, to those that remained he said, “Let
us arise and go up against our enemies, if possible we are able to defeat them.” But they pleaded with him saying, “We shall never
be able! Let us now rather save our lives, and afterward we will return with our brothers, and fight against them, for we are but a few.” Then Yahuḏah said, “Elohim forbid that I should do
this matter, and flee away from them. If our time has come, let us die bravely for our brothers, and let us not stain our honour.” With that, the army of Bakḵidĕs moved out of their

tents, and stood opposite them; their horsemen being divided into two companies, and their slingers and archers going before the army. And those that marched in the front were all mighty men. As for Bakḵidĕs, he was in the right wing. So the
army drew near to the two divisions, and sounded their trumpets. Those of Yahuḏah’s side, even they also sounded
their trumpets, so that the earth shook at the noise of the armies, and the battle continued from morning till night. Now when Yahuḏah perceived that Bakḵidĕs and
the strength of his army were on the right side, he took with him all the brave men, who defeated the right wing, and pursued them to
Mount Ashdoḏ. But when those on the left wing saw that those on
the right wing were defeated, they pursued Yahuḏah, 1468
were slain on both sides. Yahuḏah was also killed, and the remnant fled.
Then Yahonathan and Shim’on took Yahuḏah their
brother, and buried him in the tomb of his fathers in Modi’im. And they mourned him, and all Yisra’ĕl made a
great lamentation for him, and mourned many days, saying, “How the brave man has fallen that delivered
Yisra’ĕl!” As for the other matters concerning Yahuḏah and
his battles, and the mighty deeds which he did, and his greatness, are they not written; for they were very many. Now after the death of Yahuḏah, the wicked began
to lift their heads in all the coasts of Yisra’ĕl, and there arose all those doing wickedness. In those days there was also a very great scarcity
of food; the land revolted because of this, and went with them. Then Bakḵidĕs chose these wicked men, and made
them masters of the land. And they made inquiry and sought for Yahuḏah’s
friends, and brought them to Bakḵidĕs, who took vengeance on them, and mistreated them. So was there a great affliction in Yisrael, the like of
which was not seen, since the time that a naḇi was among them. Because of this, all Yahuḏah’s companions came
together, and said to Yahonathan, “Since your brother Yahuḏah died, we have no man
like him to go out against our enemies, and Bakḵidĕs, and against those of our nation that are adversaries to us. 1469
our leader and captain in his place, that you may fight our battles.” Therefore, at that time Yahonathan took the
authority upon himself, and rose up instead of his brother Yahuḏah. But when Bakḵidĕs learned of this, he sought to
slay him. Then Yahonathan, and Shim’on his brother, and all
that were with him, perceiving this, fled into the wilderness of Teqowa, and pitched their tents by the water of the pool Asphar. When Bakḵidĕs knew, he came near to the Yardĕn
with all his army on the Shabbath day. Now Yahonathan had sent his brother Yoḥanan, a
captain of the people, to ask his friends the Naḇothites, that they might leave with them their goods, which was much. But the children of Yambri came out of Mĕyḏeḇa,
and took Yoḥanan, and all that he had, and went their way with it. After this, word came to Yahonathan and Shim’on

his brother, that the children of Yambri held a great marriage, and were bringing the bride, the daughter of one of the great princes of Kena’an from Naḏaḇath, with a great procession. Therefore they remembered Yoḥanan their brother,
and went up, and hid themselves under cover of the mountain, where they lifted up their eyes, and looked, and,

see, there was a great tumult and a great procession. And the bridegroom came out, and his friends and brothers, to meet them with tambourines and music and many instruments. Then Yahonathan and those that were with him
rose up against them from the place where they lay in ambush, and made a slaughter of them, so that many 1470
the noise of their song into lamentation. So when they had fully avenged the blood of their
brother, they turned again to the wadi of the Yardĕn. Now when Bakḵidĕs heard of this, he came on the
Shabbath day to the banks of the Yardĕn with a great force. Then Yahonathan said to his army, “Let us go up
now and fight for our lives, for it does not stand with us today, as in time past. “For, see, the battle is before us and behind us, and
the water of the Yardĕn on this side and that side, the wadi and also the forest, neither is there a place for us to turn aside. “Therefore cry out now to the shamayim, that you
may be delivered from the hand of your enemies.” Therefore, they joined battle, and Yahonathan
stretched out his hand to smite Bakḵidĕs, but he turned back from him. Then Yahonathan and those that were with him
leaped into the Yardĕn, and swam over to the other bank; however, the others did not pass over the Yardĕn to them. So about one thousand men of Bakḵidĕs’ army
were slain that day. Afterward Bakḵidĕs returned to Yerushalayim and

repaired the strong cites in Yahuḏah, the fort in Yeriḥo and Amma’us and Bĕyth Ḥoron and Bĕyth Ĕl and Timnathah, Pirathon and Tsaphon. He strengthened these with high walls, with gates and with bars. And he appointed a garrison in them, that they
might do evil to Yisra’ĕl. He also fortified the city of Bĕyth Tsur, and Gezer,
and the tower, and put forces in them, and provisions of food. 1471
hostages, and put them into the tower at Yerushalayim to be guarded. And in the hundred and fifty-third year, in the
second month, Elyaqim commanded that the wall of the inner court of the Miqdash should be pulled down. He also pulled down the works of the neḇi’im. And as he began to pull down, even at that time

Elyaqim was plagued, and his works were hindered; for his mouth was stopped, and he was paralysed, so that he could no longer speak a word, nor give orders concerning his house. So Elyaqim died at that time in great torment.
Now when Bakḵidĕs saw that Elyaqim was dead,
he returned to the sovereign. So the land of Yahuḏah was at rest two years. Then all the wicked men held a council, saying,
“See, Yahonathan and his company are at ease, and dwell without concern. Now therefore we will bring Bakḵidĕs here, who shall take them all in one night.” So they went and consulted with him.
Then he moved, and came with a great army, and

sent letters secretly to his supporters in Yahuḏah, that they should take Yahonathan and those that were with him. However they could not, because their counsel was known to them. Therefore they took the men of the land that were
the cause of that evil - about fifty people - and slew them. Afterward Yahonathan, and Shim’on, and those
that were with him, escaped to Bĕyth Bĕsai, which is in the wilderness, and they repaired the ruins there, and strengthened it. When Bakḵidĕs knew this, he gathered together all
his army, and sent word to those that were of Yahuḏah. 1472
And they fought against it for a long time and built siege engines. But Yahonathan left his brother Shim’on in the city,
and went out himself into the land, and with a certain number he went out. And he smote Odomera and his brothers, and the
children of Phaseiron in their tent. And when he began to smite them, and came up
with his forces, Shim’on and his army went out of the city, and burned the siege engines, and fought against Bakḵidĕs, who was defeated by
them. And they distressed him greatly, for his counsel and hardship was worthless. Therefore he was very wroth at the wicked men that
gave him counsel to come into the land, so he slew many of them, and intended to return to his own land. When Yahonathan knew of this, he sent
ambassadors to him, so that he should make peace with him, and deliver them the prisoners; which he accepted, and did according to his
demands, and swore to him that he would never do him harm all the days of his life. Therefore when he had restored the prisoners to
him that he had taken previously out of the land of Yahuḏah, he returned and went his way to his own land, neither did he come to their borders any more. Thus the sword ceased from Yisra’ĕl, and
Yahonathan dwelt at Miḵmas, and began to rule the people, and he destroyed the wicked men out of Yisra’ĕl.
In the hundred and sixtieth year, Alexandros the son of Antioḵos, also named Epiphanĕs, went up and took Ptolemais; for the people had received him, by means of which he reigned there. 1473
gathered together an exceedingly great army, and went out to fight against him. And Dĕmĕtrios sent letters to Yahonathan with kind
words, so that he exalted him. For said he, “Let us first make peace with him,
before he joins with Alexandros against us, or else he will remember all the evils that we have
done against him, and against his brothers and his people.” Therefore he gave him authority to gather together
an army, and to provide weapons, that he might aid him in battle. He also commanded that the hostages that were in the tower should be delivered to him. Then Yahonathan came to Yerushalayim and read
the letters in the hearing of all the people and of those that were in the tower, who were greatly afraid when they heard that the
sovereign had given him authority to gather together an army. So those of the tower delivered their hostages to
Yahonathan, and delivered them to their parents. This done, Yahonathan settled himself in
Yerushalayim, and began to build and repair the city. And he commanded the workmen to build the walls
and Mount Tsiyon round about with square stones for fortification; and they did so. Then the foreigners, that were in the fortresses
which Bakḵidĕs had built, fled away; so that every man left his place and went into his
own land. Only, some of those still remained at Bĕyth Tsur
that had forsaken the Law and the Commands; for it was their place of refuge. Now when Sovereign Alexandros had heard what
promises Dĕmĕtrios had sent to Yahonathan; when it was also told to him of the battles and brave deeds 1474
therefore we will make him our friend and ally.” Therefore he wrote a letter, and sent it to him,
according to these words, saying: “Sovereign Alexandros, to his brother Yahonathan,
greetings. “We have heard of you, that you are a man of great
strength, and worthy to be our friend. “Therefore now, we ordain you this day to be the

kohĕn ha’gadol of your nation, and to be called the sovereign’s friend, and require you to take our side, and maintain friendship with us.” And with all this he sent him a purple robe and a crown of gold. So in the seventh month of the hundred and sixtieth
year, at the Feast of Sukkoth, Yahonathan put on the
grieved, and said, “What have we done, that Alexandros has
prevented us in making peace with the Yahuḏim to strengthen himself? “I will also write words of encouragement to them,
and promise them esteem and gifts, that I may have their support.” Therefore he sent to them to this word: “Sovereign
Dĕmĕtrios, to the people of the Yahuḏim, greetings. “Whereas you have kept covenants with us, and
continued in our friendship, not joining yourselves with our enemies, we have heard of this, and are glad. “Therefore now continue to be still trustworthy to
us, and we will recompense you well for the matters you do on our behalf, and will grant you many exemptions, and give you
rewards. 1475
all the Yahuḏim from tributes, and from the customs of salt, and from crown taxes, and from that which pertains to me to receive of the

third part of the seed, and the half of the fruit of the trees. I release it from this day onward, so that they shall not be taken from the land of Yahuḏah, nor of the three governments which are added to them out of the country of Shomeron and Galil, from this day onward, forever.
with its borders, both from tenths and tributes. “And as for the tower which is at Yerushalayim, I
yield up authority over it, and give to the kohĕn ha’gadol, that he may appoint in it such men as he shall choose to guard it. “And I freely release every one of the Yahuḏim, that

were carried captive out of the land of Yahuḏah into any part of my reign, and I purpose that all my officers release the tributes even of their cattle. “Furthermore, I purpose that all the Feasts, and

Shabbathoth, and New Moons, and Appointed Times, and the three days before the Feast, and the three days after the Feast shall be all of tolerance and freedom for all the Yahuḏim in my reign. “Also, no man shall have authority to meddle with
or to provoke any of them in any matter. “I further purpose, that there be enrolled among the
sovereign’s forces about thirty thousand men of the Yahuḏim, to whom wages shall be given, as belongs to all sovereign’s forces. “And of them, some shall be positioned in the

sovereign’s strongholds, some of whom are trustworthy shall also be appointed over the affairs of the reign. And I purpose that their overseers and governors be from among themselves, and that they 1476

added to Yahuḏah from the country of Shomeron, let them be joined with Yahuḏah, that they may be reckoned to be under one, nor bound to obey authority other than the kohĕn ha’gadol. “As for Ptolemais, and the land pertaining to it, I
give it as a free gift to the Miqdash at Yerushalayim for the necessary expenses of the Miqdash. “And every year I give fifteen thousand shekels of
silver out of the sovereign’s accounts from the pertaining places, and all the remainder, which the officers did not pay
as in former time, from now on shall be given toward the works of the Hĕyḵal. “And besides this, the five thousand shekels of

silver which they took from the uses of the Hĕyḵal out of the accounts year by year, even those shall be released, because they pertain to the kohenim that serve. “And whoever flees to the Hĕyḵal at Yerushalayim,

or comes within these freedoms, being indebted to the sovereign, or for any other matter, let them be released, and all that they have in my reign. “Also for the building and repairing of the works of
the Miqdash, expenses shall be given from the sovereign’s accounts. “And also for the building of the walls of

Yerushalayim, and its fortifications round about, expenses shall be given out of the sovereign’s accounts, as also for the building of the walls in Yahuḏah.” Now when Yahonathan and the people heard these
words, they gave them no trust, nor received them, because they remembered the great evil that he had done in Yisra’ĕl; for he had afflicted them very greatly. 1477
because he was the first that sought true peace with them, and they were allied with him always. Then Sovereign Alexandros gathered great forces,
and encamped opposite Dĕmĕtrios. And after the two sovereigns had joined battle,
Dĕmĕtrios’ army fled, but Alexandros followed after him, and prevailed against them. And he continued the battle greatly until the sun
went down; and Dĕmĕtrios was slain that day. Afterward, Alexandros sent ambassadors to
Ptolemaeus sovereign of Mitsrayim with a message to this effect: “Since I have come again to my reign, and am
appointed to the throne of my ancestors, and have acquired the reign, and overthrown Dĕmĕtrios, and recovered our country; for after I had joined battle with him, both he and
his army were defeated by us, so that we sit on the throne of his reign. Now therefore let us make a covenant of peace
together, and give me now your daughter as wife, and I will be your son-in-law, and will give both to you and her according to your dignity.” Then Ptolemaeus the sovereign gave answer,
saying, “Joyful is the day in which you returned to the land of your fathers, and sat on the throne of their reign. “And now I will do to you, as you have written.
Therefore meet me at Ptolemais, that we may see one another; for I will marry my daughter to you according to your desire.” So Ptolemaeus went out of Mitsrayim with his
daughter Cleopatra, and they came to Ptolemais in the hundred and sixty-second year, where Sovereign Alexandros met him, gave to him
his daughter Cleopatra, and celebrated her marriage 1478
Yahonathan, that he should come and meet him, who therefore went honourably to Ptolemais, where
he met the two sovereigns, and gave they and their friends silver and gold and many gifts, and found favour in their sight. At that time some wicked men of Yisra’ĕl, men of a
Beliya’al, assembled themselves against him to accuse him; but the sovereign would not hear them. Yet furthermore, the sovereign commanded to take
off his garments, and clothe him in purple; and they did so. And he made him sit beside him, and said to his

princes, “Go with him into the midst of the city, and proclaim, that no man complain against him for any matter, and that no man trouble him for any reason.” Now when his accusers saw that he was honored
according to the proclamation, and clothed in purple, they all fled. So the sovereign honoured him, and wrote him
among his chief friends, and made him a chief, and shared in his reign. Afterward, Yahonathan returned to Yerushalayim in
peace and gladness. Furthermore, in the hundred and sixty-fifth year
Dĕmĕtrios son of Dĕmĕtrios came out of Krĕtĕ into the land of his fathers. When Sovereign Alexandros heard of this, he was
grieved, and returned to Antioḵeia. Then Dĕmĕtrios made Apollonios the governor of
Koĕlĕ Suria his general, who gathered together a great army, and encamped in Yaḇneh, and sent to Yahonathan the kohĕn ha’gadol saying, 1479
mocked for your sake and reproached, and why do you boast of your strength against us in the mountains? “Now therefore, if you trust in your own strength,
come down to us into the field of the plains, and there let us try the matter together. For the strength of the cities is with me. “Ask, and learn who I am, and the rest that take our
side, and they shall tell you that your foot is not able to flee in their own land. “Therefore now, you shall not be able to stand
against the horsemen and such a great strength in the plain, where there is neither stone nor flint, nor a place to flee to!” So when Yahonathan heard these words of
Apollonios, he was moved in his mind, and choosing ten thousand men he went out of Yerushalayim, where Shim’on his brother met him to help him. And he pitched his tents against Yapho, but those
of Yapho shut him out of the city, because Apollonios had a garrison there. Then Yahonathan laid siege against it, so those of
the city let him in for fear. And so Yahonathan won Yapho. When Apollonios heard of this, he took three

thousand horsemen, with a great army of footmen, and went to Ashdoḏ as one that journeyed, and then approached the plain, because he had a great number of horsemen, in whom he put his trust. Then Yahonathan followed after him to Ashdoḏ
where the armies joined battle. Now Apollonios had left one thousand horsemen in
ambush. And Yahonathan knew that there was an ambush
behind him; for they had surrounded his army, and shot arrows at the people, from morning till evening. 1480
commanded them, and so the enemy’s horses were tired. Then brought Shim’on out his army, and positioned
them against the footmen, for the horsemen who were defeated by him were weary, and fled. The horsemen also, being scattered in the field,
fled to Ashdoḏ, and went to the house of Daḡon, their idol’s temple, for safety. But Yahonathan lit fire to Ashdoḏ, and the cities
round about it, and took their spoils. And he burned the temple of Daḡon with fire with those that had fled into it, so there were nearly eight thousand men burned
and slain with the sword. And from there Yahonathan moved his army, and
encamped against Ashqelon, where the men of the city came out and met him with great ceremony. After this, Yahonathan and his army returned to
Yerushalayim possessing many spoils. Now, when Sovereign Alexandros heard these
matters, he honoured Yahonathan still further, and sent him a gold buckle, as is the custom to be
given to those of the sovereign’s blood. He also gave him Eqron with its borders as a possession.

And the sovereign of Mitsrayim gathered together a great army, like the sand that lies upon the sea shore, and many ships, and through deceit attempted to gain the reign of Alexandros, and join it to his own. So he departed to Spania in a peaceable manner,
so that those of the cities opened to him, and met him; for Sovereign Alexandros had commanded them to do so, because he was his brother-in-law. Now as Ptolemaeus entered into the cities, he
positioned a garrison of soldiers in every one of them to guard it. 1481

him the temple of Daḡon that was burned, and Ashdoḏ and the suburbs of there that were destroyed, and the bodies that were thrown about and those that he had burned in the battle; for they had made heaps of them by the way where he should pass. They also told the sovereign all Yahonathan had
done, to the intent he might blame him, but the sovereign held his peace. Then Yahonathan met the sovereign with great
ceremony at Yapho, where they greeted one another, and stayed. Afterward, when Yahonathan had gone with the
sovereign to the river called Eleutherus, he returned again to Yerushalayim. Therefore Sovereign Ptolemaeus, having gained
the reign of the cities by the sea to Seleukeia on the sea coast, devised wicked plans against Alexandros. So he sent ambassadors to Sovereign Dĕmĕtrios,

saying, “Come, let us make an alliance between us, and I will give you my daughter whom Alexandros has, and you shall reign in your father’s reign. “For I regret that I gave my daughter to him, for he
sought to slay me.” So he slandered him, because he desired his reign.
Therefore he took his daughter from him, and gave
her to Dĕmĕtrios, and forsook Alexandros, so that their hatred was openly known. Then Ptolemaeus came to Antioḵeia, where he
placed two crowns upon his head: the crown of Asia, and of Mitsrayim. In the winter, Sovereign Alexandros was in Kilikia,
because those that dwelt in those parts had revolted against him. But when Alexandros heard of this, he came to fight
against him; so Sovereign Ptolemaeus brought forth 1482
but Sovereign Ptolemaeus was exalted. For Zaḇdi’ĕl the Araḇian took off Alexandros’ head,
and sent it to Ptolemaeus. Sovereign Ptolemaeus also died after the third day,
and those that were in the strongholds were slain, one after another. Because of this, Dĕmĕtrios reigned in the hundred
and sixty-seventh year. At the same time Yahonathan gathered together
those that were in Yahuḏah to take the tower that was in Yerushalayim, and he built many siege engines against it. Then wicked men, who hated their own people,
went to the sovereign, and told him that Yahonathan besieged the tower. When he heard of this, he was wroth, and moving
immediately, he came to Ptolemais and wrote to Yahonathan, that he should not lay siege to the tower, but come quickly and speak with him at Ptolemais. Nevertheless, when Yahonathan heard this, he
commanded to continue the siege, and he chose some of the elders of Yisra’ĕl and the kohenim, and put himself at risk, and took silver and gold and garments, and also
various presents, and went to Ptolemais to the sovereign, where he found favour in his sight. And though some wicked men of the people had
made complaints against him, the sovereign still treated him as his predecessors
had done before, and promoted him in the sight of all his friends, and confirmed him in the high kehunnah, and in all
the honours that he had before, and made him first among his chief friends. 1483
that he would make Yahuḏah free from tribute, as also the three governments, with the country of Shomeron; and he promised him three hundred talanton. So the sovereign agreed, and wrote letters for
Yahonathan of all these matters after this manner: “Sovereign Dĕmĕtrios to his brother Yahonathan,
and to the nation of the Yahuḏim, greetings. “We send you here a copy of the letter which we
wrote to our cousin Lasthĕnĕs concerning you, that you might see it. ‘Sovereign Dĕmĕtrios to his father Lasthĕnĕss
sends greeting. “We are determined to do good to the people of the
Yahuḏim, who are our friends, and guard covenants with us, because of their favour toward us. ‘Therefore we have assigned to them the borders

of Yahuḏah, with the three governments of Ephrayim and Loḏ and Ramathayim, that are added to Yahuḏah from the country of Shomeron, and all pertaining to them, for all those who offer in Yerushalayim, instead of the payments which the sovereign received from them yearly previously out of the fruits of the earth and of trees. ‘And as for other matters that relate to us, of the
tithes and customs pertaining to us, and also the salt- pits and the crown taxes which are due to us, we release them all for their aid. ‘And none of this shall be revoked from this time on
forever. ‘Now therefore, see that you make a copy of these
matters, and let it be delivered to Yahonathan, and put
land was at peace before him, and that no resistance was made against him, he sent away all his armies, every one to his own place, except some bands of 1484

Alexandros’ group before, who, seeing that all the army grumbled against Dĕmĕtrios, went to Imalkuĕ the Araḇian that brought up Antioḵos the young son of Alexandros, and pressured him to deliver him this young

Antioḵos, that he might reign in his father’s place. So he told him of all that Dĕmĕtrios had done, and how his soldiers were at enmity with him, and he remained there a long time. In the meantime, Yahonathan sent to Sovereign
Dĕmĕtrios, that he would throw those of the tower out of Yerushalayim, and also those in the fortresses; for they fought against Yisra’ĕl. So Dĕmĕtrios sent to Yahonathan saying, “I will not
only do this for you and your people, but I will greatly honour you and your nation, if opportunity arises. “Now therefore you shall do well if you send me
men to help me; for all my forces are gone from me.” Upon this Yahonathan sent him three thousand
strong men to Antioḵeia; and when they came to the sovereign, the sovereign was very glad of their arrival. However those that were from the city gathered
themselves together into the midst of the city, numbering a hundred and twenty thousand men, and would have slain the sovereign. So the sovereign fled into the court, but those of the
city guarded the passages of the city, and began to fight. Then the sovereign called to the Yahuḏim for help,
who came to him all at once, and dispersing themselves throughout the city slew that day in the city to the number of a hundred thousand. 1485
spoils that day, and delivered the sovereign. So when those of the city saw that the Yahuḏim had
taken the city as they would, their courage decreased, therefore they made supplication to the sovereign, and cried, saying, “Grant us peace, and let the Yahuḏim cease from
assaulting us and the city!” With that, they threw down their weapons, and

made peace; and the Yahuḏim were honoured in the sight of the sovereign and in the sight of all that were in his reign; and they returned to Yerushalayim, having great spoils. So Sovereign Dĕmĕtrios sat on the throne of his
reign, and the land was at rest before him. However, he deceived in all that he spoke, and
estranged himself from Yahonathan, neither rewarded him according to the good which he had received from him, but troubled him deeply. After this, Truphon returned, and the young child
Antioḵos with him, who was crowned and reigned. Then all the men of battle gathered to him, whom
Dĕmĕtrios had put away, and they fought against Dĕmĕtrios, who turned his back and fled. Then Truphon took the elephants, and won
Antioḵeia. At that time young Antioḵos wrote to Yahonathan,
saying, “I confirm you in the high kehunnah and appoint you ruler over the four governments and to be one of the sovereign’s friends.” Then he sent him golden vessels to be served in,
allowed him to drink in gold, and to be clothed in purple, and to wear a golden buckle. He also made Shim’on his brother captain of the
place called ‘The ladder of Tsor’ to the borders of Mitsrayim. 1486

the cities beyond the waters, and all the forces of Suria gathered themselves to him to assist him. And when he came to Ashqelon, those of the city met him honourably. From there he went to Azzah, but those of Azzah
shut him out, so he laid siege to it, and burned the open lands with fire, and plundered them. Afterward, when those of Azzah made supplication

to Yahonathan, he made peace with them, and took the sons of their chief men for hostages, and sent them to Yerushalayim, and passed through the country to Dammeseq. Now when Yahonathan heard that the princes of
Dĕmĕtrios had come to Qaḏĕsh, which is in Galil, with a great force, with the purpose of removing him out of the land, he went to meet them, and left Shim’on his brother
in the land. Then Shim’on encamped against Bĕyth Tsur and
fought against it a long time, and shut it up. But they desired for peace with him, which he
granted them, and then put them out from there, and took the city, and positioned a garrison in it. As for Yahonathan and his army, they encamped at
the lake of Gennĕsar, and early in the morning they went from there to the plain of Ḥatsor. And see, the army of foreigners met them in the
plain, who, having laid men in ambush for him in the mountains, they came opposite him. So when those that lay in ambush rose out of their
places and joined battle, all that were of Yahonathan’s side fled; so that there was not one of them left, except
Mattithyahu the son of Aḇshalom, and Yahuḏah the son of Ḥalphi, the captains of the army. 1487
dust upon his head, and prayed. After turning again to battle, he put them to flight,
and so they ran away. Now when his own men that had fled saw this, they
turned again toward him, and with him, pursued them to Qaḏĕsh, even to their own tents, and there they encamped. So there were slain that day about three thousand
men of the gentiles, but Yahonathan returned to Yerushalayim.
Now when Yahonathan saw that time served him, he chose some men, and sent them to Rome, to confirm and renew the alliance that they had with them. He also sent letters to the Lakedaemonians, and to
other places, for the same purpose. So they went to Rome, and entered into the senate,
and said, “Yahonathan the kohĕn ha’gadol, and the people of the Yahuḏim, sent us to you, so that you should renew the friendship which you had with them, and alliance as before.”
governors of every place that they should bring them into the land of Yahuḏah peaceably. And this is the copy of the letters which Yahonathan
wrote to the Lakedaemonians: “Yahonathan the kohĕn ha’gadol, and the elders of
the nation, and the kohenim, and the other of the Yahuḏim, to the Lakedaemonians their brothers, greetings. “There were letters sent in time past to Onyah the
kohĕn ha’gadol from Dareyawesh, who then reigned among you, to signify that you are our brothers, as the copy here underwritten specifies; at which time Onyah entreated the ambassador
that was sent honourably, and received the letters, in 1488
renewing of brotherhood and friendship, lest we should become strangers to you altogether; for a long time has passed since you sent to us. “We therefore at all times without ceasing, both in

our Feasts, and other convenient days, remember you in the slaughterings which we offer, and in our prayers, as is right, and as it is fitting for us to think upon our brothers, and we are rightly pleased for your honour.
“As for ourselves, we have had great troubles and
battles on every side, because the sovereigns that are round about us have fought against us. “However, we would not be troublesome to you, nor
to others of our allies and friends, in these battles, for we have help from the shamayim that upholds
us, so that we are delivered from our enemies, and our enemies are brought under foot. “For this cause we chose Numĕnios the son of
Antioḵos, and Antipater the son of Yason, and sent
greet and to deliver you our letters concerning the renewing of our brotherhood. “Therefore now you shall do well to give us an
answer to this.” And this is the copy of the letters which he sent to
Onyah: “Arĕios sovereign of the Lakedaemonians to Onyah
the kohĕn ha’gadol; greetings. 1489
Yahuḏim are brothers, and that they are of the race of Aḇraham. “Now therefore, since this has come to our
knowledge, you shall do well to write to us of your prosperity. “We write back again to you, that your cattle and
goods are ours, and ours are yours. We command therefore our ambassadors to make report to you in this way.” Now when Yahonathan heard that Dĕmĕtrios’
princes had come to fight against him with a greater army than before, he moved from Yerushalayim, and met them in the
land of Amathos; for he gave them no release to enter his country. He also sent spies to their tents, who came again,
and told him that they were positioned to attack them in the night. Therefore, as soon as the sun was down,

Yahonathan commanded his men to be armed and to watch all night long so that they would be ready to fight. He also sent out watchmen round about the army. But when the adversaries heard that Yahonathan
and his men were ready for battle, they feared, and trembled in their hearts, and they kindled fires in their camp. However Yahonathan and his army did not know it
till the morning; for they saw the lights burning. Then Yahonathan pursued after them, but did not
overtake them, for they had passed over the River Eleutherus. Therefore Yahonathan turned to the Araḇians, who
were called Zaḇaḏeans, and smote them, and took their spoils. And moving from there, he came to Dammeseq,
and so passed through all the land. 1490
to Ashqelon and the towers beside there, from where he turned aside to Yapho, and took it, for he had heard that they would deliver the
stronghold to those that allied with Dĕmĕtrios; therefore he positioned a garrison there to guard it. After this, Yahonathan returned home again, and
calling the elders of the people together, he consulted with them about building strongholds in Yahuḏah, and making the walls of Yerushalayim higher, and

raising a great mound between the tower and the city to separate it from the city, so that it might stand alone, that men might neither sell nor buy in it. Upon this they came together to build up the city,
because part of the wall toward the wadi on the east side had fallen down, and they repaired that which was called Kaphenatha. Shim’on also built up Aḏiḏa in Shephelah, and
strengthened if with gates and bars. Now Truphon went about to take the reign of Asia,
and to kill Antioḵos the sovereign, that he might place the crown upon his own head. However he was afraid that Yahonathan would not

allow him, and that he would fight against him; therefore he sought a way how to take Yahonathan, that he might kill him. So he moved, and came to Bĕyth She’an. Then Yahonathan went out to meet him with forty
thousand men chosen for the battle, and came to Bĕyth She’an. Now when Truphon saw Yahonathan come with so
great a force, he dared not stretch out his hand against him; but received him honourably, and commended him
to all his friends, and gave him gifts, and commanded his men of battle to be as obedient to him, as to himself. 1491
brought all this people such great trouble, seeing there is no battle between us? “Now therefore, send them home again, and

choose a few men to wait on you, and you, come with me to Ptolemais, for I will give it to you, and the rest of the strongholds and forces, and all that have any charge. As for me, I will return and depart, for this is why I have come.” So Yahonathan believing him, did as he asked him,
and sent away his army, who went into the land of Yahuḏah. And he only kept three thousand men with himself,
of which he sent two thousand into Galil, and one thousand went with him. Now as soon as Yahonathan entered into
Ptolemais, those of Ptolemais shut the gates and took him, and all those that came with him they slew with the sword. Then Truphon sent an army of footmen and
horsemen into Galil, and into the great plain to destroy all Yahonathan’s army. But when they knew that Yahonathan and those
that were with him were taken and slain, they encouraged one another, and drew close together preparing to fight. Therefore those that pursued them, seeing that
they were ready to fight for their lives, turned back again. So they all came into the land of Yahuḏah

peaceably, and there they mourned for Yahonathan, and those that were with him, and they were very afraid. And so all Yisra’ĕl made a great lamentation. Then all the gentiles that were round about sought
to destroy them, for they said, “They have no captain, nor any to help them. Now therefore let us fight them, and take away their remembrance from among men.” 1492
Now when Shim’on heard that Truphon had gathered together a great army to invade the land of Yahuḏah, and destroy it, and seeing that the people were in great trembling
and fear, went up to Yerushalayim, and gathered the people together, and gave them encouragement, saying, “You

yourselves know what great deeds my brothers and I and my father’s house have done for the Laws and the Miqdash; also the battles and troubles which we have seen. “For this reason all my brothers are slain for
Yisra’ĕl’s sake, and I alone am left. “Now therefore, far be it from me that I should spare
my own life in any time of trouble, for I am no better than my brothers. “Certainly I shall avenge my nation, and the
Miqdash and our wives and our children; for all the gentiles are gathered with great evil to destroy us.” Now as soon as the people heard these words their
spirit revived, and they answered with a loud voice saying, “You
shall be our leader instead of Yahuḏah and Yahonathan your brother!” “You fight our battles, and whatever, you command
us, that we shall do.” So then he gathered together all the men of battle,
and made haste to finish the walls of Yerushalayim, and he fortified it round about. He also sent Yahonathan the son of Aḇshalom, and
a great force with him to Yapho, who throwing out those that were there, remained there in it. So Truphon moved from Ptolemais with a great
strength to invade the land of Yahuḏah, and Yahonathan was with him under guard. 1493
plain. Now when Truphon knew that Shim’on had risen up
instead of his brother Yahonathan, and meant to fight with him, he sent messengers to him, saying, “Although we have Yahonathan your brother under
guard, it is for silver that he owes to the sovereign’s treasury, concerning that which was delivered to him. “Now therefore, send a hundred talanton of silver
and two of his sons as hostages, that when he is released he may not revolt against us, and we will let him go.” Although Shim’on perceived that they spoke
deceitfully to him, because of this he sent the silver and the children, lest he should possibly gain great hatred for himself from the people, who might have said, “Because he did not send him
the silver and the children, therefore Yahonathan is dead.” So he sent them the children and the hundred
talanton. However, Truphon was deceitful, neither would he let Yahonathan go. And after this, Truphon came to invade the land and
destroy it, going round about by the way that leads to Aḏorayim. But Shim’on and his army marched against him in every place, wherever he went. Now those that were in the tower sent messengers
to Truphon, so that he should hasten his coming to them by the wilderness, and send them food. Therefore Truphon prepared all his horsemen to
come that night, but he did not come because a very great snow fell. So he departed, and came into the land of Gil’aḏ. And when he came near to Baskama he slew
Yahonathan, who was buried there. Afterward Truphon returned and went into his own
land. 1494
Yahonathan his brother, and buried them in Modi’im, the city of his fathers, and all Yisra’ĕl made a great lamentation for him,
and mourned for him many days. Shim’on also built a monument upon the tomb of
his father and his brothers, and raised it up to be seen, with hewn stone in front and behind. And, he put up seven memorials, one against
another, for his father, and his mother, and his four brothers. And in these he made skilled works, around which

he placed great column. And he placed all their armour upon the columns for a remembrance forever, and ships were carved by the armour, that they might be seen of all that sail on the sea. This is the tomb which he made at Modi’im, and it
still stands to this day. Now Truphon dealt deceitfully with the young
Sovereign Antioḵos, and slew him, and he reigned in his place, and crowned himself
sovereign of Asia, and brought great distress upon the land. Then Shim’on built up the strongholds in Yahuḏah,
and walled them around with high towers, and great walls, and gates, and bars, and stored up food within. And Shim’on chose men, and sent to Sovereign
Dĕmĕtrios so that he would give the land immunity, because all that Truphon did was to plunder; unto whom Sovereign Dĕmĕtrios answered and
wrote after this manner: “Sovereign Dĕmĕtrios, to Shim’on the kohĕn
ha’gadol, and friend of sovereigns, also to the elders and nation of the Yahuḏim, greetings. “The golden crown, and the scarlet robe which you
sent to us, we have received, and we are ready to make lasting peace with you, and also to write to our 1495
shall stand, and the strongholds which you have built shall be your own. “As for any oversight or fault committed to this day,
we forgive it, and also the crown tax which you owe us. And if there were any other tribute paid in Yerushalayim, it shall no longer be paid. “And seek those who are upright among you to be
in our court; let them be enrolled, and let there be peace between us.” Thus the yoke of the gentiles was taken away from
Yisra’ĕl in the hundred and seventieth year. Then the people of Yisra’ĕl began to write in their
and besieged it round about. He also made a siege engine, and positioned it by the city, and battered a certain tower, and took it. And those that were in the siege engine leaped into
the city; therefore there was such a great uproar in the city, that the people of the city tore their garments, and
climbed up on the walls with their wives and children, and cried with a loud voice pleading for Shim’on to grant them peace. And they said, “Do not deal with us according to our
wickedness, but according to your kindness!” So Shim’on was appeased toward them and no
longer fought against them, but put them out of the city, and cleansed the houses in which the idols were, and so entered into it with songs and thanksgiving. He also removed all its uncleanness, and
appointed men there that would guard the Law, and 1496

so restricted, that they could neither come out, nor go into the country, nor buy, nor sell. Therefore they were in great distress for need of food, and a great number of them perished through scarcity of food. Then they cried to Shim’on, pleading for him to be
at one with them, which he granted them. And when he had put them out from there, he cleansed the tower from uncleannesses, and entered into it on the twenty-third day of the

second month, in the hundred and seventy-first year with thanksgiving and branches of palm trees, and with harps and cymbals and with stringed instruments, and songs of praise and songs; because a great enemy was destroyed out of Yisra’ĕl. He also ordained that the day should be kept every
year with gladness. And he made the hill of the Hĕyḵal that was by the tower stronger than it was, and he dwelt there himself with his army. And when Shim’on saw that Yoḥanan his son was
a brave man, he made him captain of all the armies; and he dwelt in Gezer.
Now in the hundred and seventy-second year Sovereign Dĕmĕtrios gathered his forces together, and went into Maḏai to gain help to fight against Truphon. But when Arsakĕs, the sovereign of Paras and
Maḏai, heard that Dĕmĕtrios had entered within his borders, he sent one of his princes to take him alive, who went and smote the army of Dĕmĕtrios, and
took him and brought him to Arsakĕs, by whom he was put under guard. As for the land of Yahuḏah, it was quiet all the days
of Shim’on; for he sought the good of his nation in 1497
this, that he took Yapho for a harbour, and made an entrance to the islands of the sea, and enlarged the boundary of his nation, and
recovered the land, and gathered together a great number of captives,
and had the reign of Gezer, and Bĕyth Tsur, and the tower, out of the which he took all uncleanness, neither was there any that resisted him. Then they tilled their ground in peace, and the earth
gave its increase, and the trees of the field their fruit. All the old men sat in the streets, speaking good
words together, and the young men put on splendid armour. He provided food for the cities, and appointed in
them all manner of fortification, so that his honourable name was known to the ends of the world. He made peace in the land, and Yisra’ĕl rejoiced
with great joy, for every man sat under his vine and his fig tree,
and there was none to trouble them, neither was there any left in the land to fight against
them. The sovereigns themselves were also overthrown in those days, and he strengthened all those of his people that
were brought low. He searched out the Law, and he removed every despiser of the Law and wicked person. He adorned the Miqdash, and multiplied vessels for
the Hĕyḵal. Now when it was heard in Rome, and as far as
Sparta, that Yahonathan was dead, they were very sorry, 1498
was made kohĕn ha’gadol in his place, and ruled the country, and the cities there, they wrote to him on tablets of bronze, to renew the
friendship and alliance which they had made with Yahuḏah and Yahonathan his brothers; writings which were read before the assembly at
Yerushalayim. And this is the copy of the letters that the

Lakedaemonians sent: “The rulers of the Lakedaemonians, with the city, to Shim’on the kohĕn ha’gadol, and the elders, and kohenim, and remnant of the people of the Yahuḏim, our brothers, greetings. “The ambassadors that were sent to our people
informed us of your esteem and honour, therefore we were glad of their coming, and registered the words that they spoke in the

council of the people in this manner: ‘Numĕnios son of Antioḵos, and Antipater son of Yason, the Yahuḏim’s ambassadors, came to us to renew the friendship they had with us, and it pleased the people to receive the men

honourably, and to put the copy of their message in public record, so that the people of the Lakedaemonians might have a memorial of it. Furthermore we have written a copy of it to Shim’on the kohĕn ha’gadol.’ ” After this Shim’on sent Numĕnios to Rome with a
great golden shield of one thousand minas weight to confirm the alliance with them. When the people heard of this, they said, “What
thanks shall we give to Shim’on and his sons? “For he and his brothers and the house of his father
have established Yisra’ĕl, and chased away their enemies from them in battle, and confirmed their freedom.” 1499

they placed on columns in Mount Tsiyon. And this is the copy of the writing: “The eighteenth day of the month Elul, in the hundred and seventy-second year, being the third year of Shim’on the kohĕn ha’gadol, at Asaramel in the great assembly of the kohenim
and people and rulers of the nation and elders of the country, these words were declared to us. “Since many times there have been battles in the

country, for which the maintenance of their Miqdash, and the Law, Shim’on the son of Mattithyahu, of the descendants of Yariḇ, together with his brothers, put themselves in danger, and resisting the enemies of their nation did their nation great honour. “For after Yahonathan, having gathered his nation
together, and been their kohĕn ha’gadol, was added to his people, their enemies prepared to invade their country, that
they might destroy it, and lay hands on the Miqdash. “At which time Shim’on rose up, and fought for his
nation, and spent much of his own wealth, and armed the brave men of his nation and gave them wages, and fortified the cities of Yahuḏah, together with
Bĕyth Tsur that lies on the borders of Yahuḏah, where the armour of the enemies had been before; but he positioned a garrison of Yahuḏim there. “He also fortified Yapho, which lies on the coast,

and Gezer, that borders on Ashdoḏ, where the enemies had dwelt before. And he appointed Yahuḏim there, and supplied them with all matters necessary for its repairs.” So the people sang the deeds of Shim’on, and to

what esteem he thought to bring his nation, making him their governor and chief kohĕn, because he had done all these matters, and for the Right-Ruling and belief which he guarded for his nation, and that by all means he sought to exalt his people. 1500
that the gentiles were taken out of their country, and also those that were in the city of Dawiḏ in Yerushalayim who had made themselves a tower from which they came out and polluted all around the
the safety of the country and the city, and raised up the walls of Yerushalayim. Sovereign Dĕmĕtrios also confirmed him in the
high kehunnah according to those matters, and made him one of his friends, and honoured him
with great honour.
called the Yahuḏim their friends and allies and brothers; and that they had entertained the ambassadors of Shim’on honourably. Also that the Yahuḏim and kohenim were well
pleased that Shim’on should be their governor and kohĕn ha’gadol forever, until there should arise a trustworthy naḇi. That he should also be their leader, and would take
charge of the Miqdash, to appoint them over their works, and over the country, and over the armoury, and over the fortresses. Besides this, that he should be obeyed by every
man, and that all the writings in the country should be made in his name, and that he should be clothed in purple and wear gold. Also that it should be not allowed for the people or

kohenim to break any of these matters, or to refute his words, or to gather an assembly in the country without him, or to be clothed in purple, or wear a gold buckle; and whoever should do otherwise, or break any of
these matters should be punished. So it pleased all the people to establish Shim’on,
and to do as had been said. 1501
to be kohĕn ha’gadol, and leader and governor of the Yahuḏim and kohenim, and to defend them all. So they commanded that this writing should be put
on tablets of bronze, and that they should be put up within the surrounds of the Miqdash in a conspicuous place; also that the copies of this should be stored in the
treasury, so that Shim’on and his sons might have them.

Now Antioḵos son of Dĕmĕtrios the sovereign sent letters from the islands of the sea to Shim’on the kohĕn and prince of the Yahuḏim, and to all the people; the contents of which were these: “Sovereign
Antioḵos to Shim’on the kohĕn ha’gadol and leader of his nation, and to the people of the Yahuḏim, greetings. “Since some troublesome men have usurped the

reign of our fathers, and my purpose is to challenge it again that I may restore it to the old estate, and to that end have gathered a multitude of foreign soldiers together and prepared ships of battle; my purpose also being to go through the country
that I may be avenged of those that have destroyed it and made many cities in the reign desolate. “Now therefore I confirm to you all the offerings
which the sovereigns before me granted you, and also whatever gifts they granted. “I allow you to coin silver for your country with your
own stamp. “And concerning Yerushalayim and the Miqdash;
let them be free, and all the armour that you have made, and fortresses that you have built, and keep in your hands, let them remain with you. 1502
sovereign, let it be forgiven you from this time on forever. “Furthermore, when we have obtained our reign,
we will honour you, and your nation, and your Hĕyḵal, with great honour, so that your honour shall be known throughout the world.” In the hundred and seventy-fourth year Antioḵos
went into the land of his fathers, at which time all the forces came together to him, so that few were left with Truphon. Therefore being pursued by Sovereign Antioḵos,
he fled to Dora, which lies by the sea coast, for he saw that troubles came upon him all at once,
and that his forces had deserted him. Then Antioḵos encamped against Dora, having
with him a hundred and twenty thousand men of battle, and eight thousand horsemen. And when he had surrounded the city and linked
ships close to the town on the sea coast, he troubled the city by land and by sea, neither did he allow any to go out or in. In the winter Numĕnios and his army came from
Rome, having letters to the sovereigns and countries in which were written these matters:
Ptolemaeus, greetings. “The Yahuḏim’s ambassadors, our friends and
allies, came to us to renew the old friendship and alliance, being sent from Shim’on the kohĕn ha’gadol and from the people of the Yahuḏim, and they brought a gold shield of one thousand
minas. “We thought it good therefore to write to the
sovereigns and countries, that they should do them no harm, nor fight against them, their cities, or countries, nor indeed aid their enemies against them. 1503
from them. “If therefore there are any troublesome fellows, that
have fled from their country to you, deliver them to Shim’on the kohĕn ha’gadol, that he may punish them according to their own Law.” He also wrote the same words to Dĕmĕtrios the
sovereign, and Attalus, to Ariarathĕs, and Arsakĕs, and to all the countries and to Lampsakos, and the
Lakedaemonians and to Dĕlos and Mundos and Sikion
kohĕn ha’gadol. So Antioḵos the sovereign encamped against Dora
the second day, assaulting it continually, and making siege engines by which means he shut up Truphon, that he could neither go out nor go in. At that time Shim’on sent him two thousand chosen
men to aid him; also silver and gold and much armour. Nevertheless he would not receive them, but broke
all the covenants which he had made with him before, and became hostile toward him. Furthermore he sent Athĕnobius, one of his friends
to him, to speak with him, and say, “You withhold Yapho and Gezer - with the tower that is in Yerushalayim - which are cities of my reign. “You have destroyed its borders, and done great
evil in the land, and taken the rule of many places within my reign. “Now therefore, deliver the cities which you have
taken, and the tributes of the places, of which you have taken rule outside the borders of Yahuḏah; or else give me five hundred talanton of silver for
them and for the damage that you have done, and the 1504

Yerushalayim, and when he saw the esteem of Shim’on, and the storage of gold and silver plate and his great attendance, he was astonished and told him the sovereign’s message. Then Shim’on answered and said to him, “We have

neither taken other men’s land, nor held that which belongs to others, but the inheritance of our fathers which our enemies held wrongfully in possession for a certain time. “Therefore we, having opportunity, hold the
inheritance of our fathers. “And whereas you demand Yapho and Gezer -
although they did great harm to the people in our country - yet we will give you a hundred talanton for them.” To this Athĕnobius answered him not a word, but returned in a rage to the sovereign, and
reported these words to him, and of the esteem of Shim’on, and of all that he had seen. So the sovereign was exceedingly wroth. In the meantime, Truphon fled by ship to Orthosia.
Then the sovereign made Kendĕbeus captain of
the sea coast, and gave him an army of footmen and horsemen, and commanded him to move his army toward

Yahuḏah. He also commanded him to build up Qiḏron, and to fortify the gates, and to fight against the people. But as for the sovereign himself, he pursued Truphon. So Kendĕbeus came to Yaḇneh and began to
provoke the people and to invade Yahuḏah, and to take the people captive and slay them. And when he had built up Qiḏron, he positioned
horsemen there, and an army of footmen, so that coming out they might make attacks on the roads to Yahuḏah, as the sovereign had commanded him. 1505
Then Yoḥanan came up from Gezer, and told Shim’on his father what Kendĕbeus had done. Therefore Shim’on called his two eldest sons

Yahuḏah and Yoḥanan and said to them, “My brothers and I and my father’s house have from my youth to this day always fought against the enemies of Yisra’ĕl. And matters have prospered so well in our hands, that we have delivered Yisra’ĕl many times. “But now I am old, and you, by Elohim’s kindness,
are of a sufficient age. You take the place of myself and my brother, and go and fight for our nation, and the help the shamayim be with you.” So he chose twenty thousand men of battle out of
the country with horsemen, who went out against Kendĕbeus, and rested that night at Modi’im. And when as they rose in the morning, and went
into the plain, see, a mighty great army of both footmen and horsemen came against them. However, there was a wadi of water between them, so he and his people encamped opposite them. But
when he saw that the people were afraid to go over the wadi of water, he went over first himself, and then the men seeing him, passed over after him. That done, he divided his men, and positioned the
horsemen in the midst of the footmen, for the enemy’s horsemen were very numerous.
Kendĕbeus and his army were put to flight, so that many of them were slain, and the remnant went to the stronghold. At that time Yahuḏah, Yoḥanan’s brother was
wounded; but Yoḥanan still pursued them until he came to Qiḏron which Kendĕbeus had built. So they fled even to the towers in the fields of
Ashdoḏ; therefore he burned it with fire, so that there 1506
Aboubus was made captain, and he had an abundance of silver and gold, for he was the kohĕn ha’gadol’s son-in-law.
Therefore his heart being lifted up, he thought to
take the land for himself, and therefore planned deceitfully against Shim’on and his sons to destroy them. Now Shim’on was visiting the cities that were in the

country and taking care for the good ordering of them; at which time he himself came down to Yeriḥo with his sons Mattithyahu and Yahuḏah, in the hundred and seventy-seventh year, in the eleventh month called Sheḇat, where the son of Aboubus, receiving them
deceitfully into a small fortress called Doḵ - which he had built - made them a great feast. However, he had men hidden there. So when Shim’on and his sons had drunk plenty,

Ptolemaeus and his men rose up, and took their weapons, and came upon Shim’on into the feasting place, and slew him, and his two sons, and some of his servants. In doing so, he committed a great treachery, and
repaid evil for good. Then Ptolemaeus wrote these matters, and sent to
the sovereign, that he should send him an army to aid him, and he would deliver him the land and cities. He also sent others to Gezer to kill Yoḥanan. And
he sent letters to the tribunes to come to him, that he might give them silver and gold and rewards. And others he sent to take Yerushalayim and the
mountain of the Hĕyḵal. 1507
that his father and brothers were slain, and he said, “Ptolemaeus has sent to slay you also.” When he heard of this, he was greatly astonished,
so he took hold of those that came to destroy him, and slew them; for he knew that they sought to take him away.
battles, and worthy deeds which he did, and the building of the walls which he made, and his doings, see, these are written in the chronicles of his
kehunnah, from the time he was made kohĕn ha’gadol after his father. 1508
